Entry.1:
8.30 am I embarked on Star of Victoria at Wool’loo Bay. During the morning I had nothing to do but watch the loading of the Horses which was done quickly & without hitch the whole lot of some 450 odd horses being put on shortly before 12 md Having said goodbye to Mother & Father who were on the wharf, & all being on board. We got under way about 12 md amidst much cheering from relatives & friends of the troops. We moved slowly down to Cremorne Bay where we anchored in company with the Clan Macquorqudale. During that afternoon we all shook down to our new surroundings & at 5 pm I attended to a small Sick Parade at the Hospital which was is right aft & just above the propeller. Here was there is much noise vibration & on both sides of the Hospital separated

only by a narrow passage are horses.

The Hospital in this part of the ship consists of 3 so called wards 2 of which contained 4 bunks (2 tiers) & the other (marked down as the Isolation ward) contained 2 bunks. This latter would be I should say barely 8 ft by 8 ft. Another Room attached & about same size we intended for the use of Venereal patients a no. of whom had been brought aboard apparently in defiance of the regulations this by order I believe of the C.O., himself a medico.

Another small box of a Room adjacent we used as a dispensary

In addition to this however there was more Hospital Accomodation provided on the Marconi Deck at Port side. This was a well ventilated wooden room in which were 6 beds. So altogether we had 16 beds. I believe only for the Captain of the Ship remonstrating we would not have had the latter at all. As regards a room suitable to be made into say a Casualty Room & operating theatre combined There was none. I accordingly arranged to do all Cas work in one of the 4 bunk Cabins in the Hospital Aft. Here we rigged up the Steriliser & got ready in a tray instruments for Casualty work. As regards a supply of water. This had to be conveyed in a tin can some little distance. However there was plenty of Iodine so we determined that at any rate Antisepsis rather than Asepsis

would prevail.

During Afternoon we were inspected for last time by the transport officers & were treated to lively lines by the Artillery Band which went round & round the transports in a launch specially hired for the occasion. On this also were many friends of those on board.

At 6 pm we had dinner which was well cooked plenty of it & varied. After Dinner I felt the natural thing was to go into the City but then I remembered where I was & felt it was not to be. Instead I talked to the S.M.O. & then about 10 pm went to bed after taking Chloretone, Qr X. which I had started 4th hrly about 2 pm

Next morning
Entry.2:
We were all up before 6 am as at that time we were due to leave Sydney We started the Clan

leaving first then ourselves (the Star of Victoria) and Euripides last We passed quietly & quickly down the Harbour & before we had time to realise it had passed outside the Heads & dropped the Pilot. Then I began to notice that the water was not smooth & that the boat was rolling a good deal & that I was in spite of the Chloretone beginning to feel green

Well I was sick then went down to Breakfast came up after having some Porridge & shortly after lost that.

However at Lunch time I felt well again & have never felt sick since & have not missed a meal

Down the Coast we kept in sight of land & one could recognise the Headlands around Bulli, Woollongong etc .

That afternoon I did the sick parade at 5 pm & admitted a man with a throat very suspicious of Diptheria He got Antitoxin of which we have a very small supply on board & his throat painted w Iodine He was quite well in 3 days.

Wednesday 21st Got up before 6 am Coast still in sight but now outside Victoria. Had a bath with sponge & bucket of fresh water. (Yesterday foolishly had a salt water bath & wondered why I could not get up a lather).

Dressed leisurely & attended Sick Parade 7 am. From this I admitted 3 or 4 men with Feverishness, running noses & sore throats. The Start of an Influenza Epidemic on board 8 am Breakfast. 9 am Went around Hospital with S.M.O. Fullerton. This took about 20 minutes largely owing to fact that we have put

in charge of Hospital 2 Naval Sick Bay Attendants. These men came out to go away with Hospital Ship Gran but were too late to catch her so are now on their way back to Navy They have been many years in Navy & thoroughly know Hospital work their knowledge apparently is quite equivalent to that of a Sister in Sydney Hospital & vastly superior to those indifferent beings we make wards men in Sydney Hospital They even are trained in Laboratory work & can stain for K L T B etc & know them when they see them. In fact they were very disappointed when I told them I did not have a microscope as they wished to look for K L in the ?Diphtheritics throat.

Our own A M C men beside them are raw material. The latter to no. of 5 were detailed as follows

Corporal Gabriel in charge of Dispensary quite smartest of lot, has done assaying so knows a bit about Chemistry rather green on Dispensing but very eager to pick it up & knows rudiments already. However as most drugs are in Tabloid form & made up as Stock mixtures he cannot make any serious mistakes. L. Corp Scott a good worker put in charge of Venereal Squadron all of whom are Gen except one who is undoubtedly d. These to no of 6 he vigorously syringes out about 3 times a day.

Ptes Rye, Gillies & Tomkins, the 1st a rather sharp looking fellow (cannot quite size him up yet) I think he feels rather superior & has rather an independent manner but quite willing to work.

Gillies rather headed (nephew of Sinclair Gillies) but willing. Tomkins an ex school master & I

should think well over 40 is rather sanctimonious in manner & speech & speaks accordingly.

He is very anxious after other peoples welfare Spiritual as well as physical (meat pie episode).

At 12 md. Had a Spar with one of Officers find it strange with ship rolling however did not get hurt & enjoyed it. The Vet officer joined me. he is a loud voiced chap always talking, generally about himself & his episodes & drinking a good deal of whisky In his Sparring he hits very hard which is not a fair thing as the men he has met so far are not his weight
Entry.3:
5.30 pm. after being out of sight of land since early morning sighted Wilsons Promontory & islands lying around we went very close & admired very much the

rough & rugged lines of coast in this part. Dinner 6 pm Bed shortly before 10 pm
Entry.4:
Passed Cape Otway early this morning, could see land dimly in distance. Will not now see any land till we get to Albany. Euripides is ahead while Clan is out of sight astern. Our Boat is doing between 300 & 310 miles per diem.

Am gradually getting to know the Ships officers

Wireless operator a very decent chap about 24. It appears he was on the "Volturno" when she was afire in Atlantic. He stuck to his post & brought the other vessells around He has a very poor opinion of the American Newspaper Reporters after that Incident.

Also yarned to Chief Engineer last night. He is a dour old chap from North of Ireland & is I believe very

careful of his coal consumption. He is quite pleased that at night we are steaming with lights out I understand It saves coal

He told me interesting tales of ships he had been on in Eastern waters one vessell he was on about 25 years ago. One day in Engine room was 128°F & in Stokehold 157°.

During today have done usual round had a few spars with the gloves stripped with Lieut Broadbent morn & evening. Latter a good type of Duntroon boy in charge of Machine Gun Section, very likeable & full of life. I think he will give a good account of himself in the war as every one else in the unit.

It gets quite monotonous at sea out of sight of land

Influenza Epidemic is increasing & have now got the Bottom & top Hospital full

no serious cases yet.
Entry.5:
much same sort of day having big sick parades & have admitted a good many today.

I wouldn’t be surprised if Horses had a good deal to do with it as a great no. of them have colds.

Watched today Horses on Main Deck taken out of their boxes & led around the deck mats being placed on the Deck to prevent them slipping. The poor beasts are very shaky & weak in the legs already & look dispirited This walking them around however does them a great deal of good However Horses are comparatively well off on our ship, in other ships I hear of some cases where there are horses away down below the water line in the Hold

This leading Horses around & Horse boxes being next to Hospital has

caused a dirty smell around that institution. However it is only the Hospital The Vet Oficer is just as dirty in the Cabin which he & I share & leaves his dirty clothes all over the Cabin an objectionable type indeed. I had a spar with him today. He is very heavy but has not much wind. He started off hitting hard so I retaliated & got him a few good hard straight lefts. Was not touched myself. Since then he has not shown so much enthusiasm for boxing
Entry.6:
Still Influenza Epidemic Have got space additional on Marconia deck canvas covered. This gives us 9 additional beds all now full Today O.C. & Vet had a race on board neither won but OC severely sprained his leg & Vet his knee.

Old enough to know better than to go running about like a two year old.

Have had usual exercise. Have by now got all Medical Stores checked We have no nail brushes & no Blue Ointment or Silver Nitrate. Will have to try & get these at Albany.
Entry.7: A quiet day with a short & sweet Service in morning nothing of note happened. We are all eagerly looking forward to tomorrow when we arrive at Albany where we will meet the other Transports Many are the Speculations concerning the Escort & how long we will stay in Albany & if we will be allowed ashore etc We are looking forward to a grand sight. The Euripides today is not in sight
Entry.8:
Everybody is awake early & up a little before 6 am We spot the land once more & everybody’s spirits rise. About 7.45 am we began to enter the Harbour between bare & desolate

looking rocky Headlands & then what a sight as we enter the Outer Harbour There before us are 25 ships at anchor Our band comes up on deck & plays patriotic airs are given & every one feels excited & I am sure thrilled by this sight before us.

We were all quite reluctant to go down to Breakfast. Outside the Harbour later on appears a Warship the Melbourne However she does not come in but stops on Guard at the entrance. We were disappointed to learn that there was to be no leave & especially so when we saw a Steam tug arrive at our vessell & see nos of the AIF on her They had got into Albany before the order was given had been stranded there a night much to their delight & were now on their way back to their ships

I at once thought of the drugs I wanted

& as the SMO was not anxious to go I thought to myself I will work this gag for all it is worth.

Later on in the day the Euripides & the Clan Mac arrived on both of which occasions our band lustily played & we stood bye to cheer.

Of course being all impatient to get to Albany once there I felt just as impatient to get away again & I was continually asking "Sparks" when we were going again. I am afraid he got rather tired of the question.
Entry.9: We are waiting for the N Z transports to come in no sign all day & no sign of departing. Influenza still going strong. Have now more room still on Marconi deck & have altogether 30 patients in Hospital. Stopping stationary & wet miserable weather in this place seems to have accentuated the Disease
Entry.10:
Getting very bored at standing still no longer see anything to enthurse over in the sight of all the transports but at 10 am our hopes arose again as we saw coming over the Horizon the N Z contingent with a Jap Warship an English & the HMAS Sydney.

Getting closer we saw the 10 N Z transports all painted gray thereby putting ours to shame & looking very well. Much was the Enthusiasm & how proud we were of our ships We never quite realised before what it was to belong to this Empire & how grateful everyone felt towards the Jap. & how we wished the Jap would only come close to us so that they could hear our cheers - but they didn’t, steamed in on the west side & after staying a short time steamed out again to sea now we felt we wont be long about getting away.
Entry.11:
I have leave from OC to proceed to Orvieto the Flag Ship to get permission to get Med Stores

We do not get off on the Tug (myself & Lt Fitzpatrick the Quatermaster who is also going to Orvieto) till 2.45 pm The Getting off was exciting. The Sea was rough & they would not put down the Gangway as it would have been smashed. We consequently had to go down the Rope ladder which we did not relish It is a long way down when you start & what with slippery boots I felt very insecure. I nearly tumbled in to the water but managed to get on to the tug after an agonising interval looking I am afraid rather undignified. During my descent the Skipper of the tug a low boy absolutely typical

of what one sees in Wor’loo had a wordy warfare with the OC who foolishly tried to tell him his job & then worse still, did a lot of futile arguing with him. We started off to do the Rounds then & went to nearly every ship in the Harbour before we got to the Orvieoto. It was very amusing to hear the comments of the crowd on each boat as we came alongside & the vigorous profanity on the part of our skipper (Tugboat) directed at various individuals who would either not catch a line or whose looks he did not like.

Particularly he took great offence when he saw a lot of grinning niggers on one boat standing by & not attempting to give a hand However when he referred to them as b— black b—ds

they appeared to wake up a little.

The tug boat rolled & pitched incessantly till I got feeling very sick then did not care a damn what happened I was much harassed by an individual who would keep talking to me. He would not let me alone & his talking made me feel steadily worse. However when he wasn’t looking I wearily staggered away to a more peaceful spot. Soon I felt better & when we drew up at the Clan Mac was able to greet old Stokes & Fiaschi & to exchange a little news. Soon after that saw Bill Kay on the Katuna looking very well & had a long shout with him (a talk I mean). Soon after saw Wassell (by that time 6 pm & later on old Dad Macartney on the Star of England.

By this time every one on Board the tug was very bored

& wondering whenever we would get to the Orvieoto. We got there at 7.45 pm tired & hungry & had to climb up a formidable rope ladder to get on board.

On Board we Met Major Austin who made us have dinner & was very decent about seeing we got it before we got our business done Having Dined in the luxurious Saloon of the Orvieto we both set about looking for the Authorities we were there to consult

After much hunting about I came across Lt Col Marshall ADDMS & shewed my list to him.

He appeared rather doubtful about getting any of the things on the list & did not think any of them necessary

He did not seem to see the

necessity of having any nail brushes for Surgical purposes at all.

However he said he would introduce me to Col Ryan, who he told me would probably bite my head off.

We met Col Ryan sitting in the Smoking Room playing bridge

He glanced at my list & at once said He would give me nothing & was very short indeed

I started to argue with him & at length persuaded him that perhaps some of the things were necessay so he grudgingly allowed me to have some of the things.

Accordingly I hunted up a Sergeant Clark of the AAMC who typed out my requirements on a proper form & then went back & found Lt Fitzpatrick

He & I then found we would

have to stay on board all night as there were no more boats going to shore that night.

We accordingly were fixed up with a Cabin & after meeting some friends of Fitzpatricks we went to bed tired out

Next Morning we were up early & had a stroll on the magnificent decks of the Orvieto She is a beautiful boat & the Deck Space available on her really surprised me. 

After Breakfast which we had with Lt Col Marshall, Dr Bird of Melbourne & General Williams I met Col Ryan who greeted me very cordially & as I had got Gen Williams consent to get most of the things on my list He signed the list at the same time hoping that I did not think he had been very

abrupt the night before. I had thought so but I quite altered my opinion concerning him in the morning I made arrangements to get on shore by the little Motor Launch which would be alongside the Orvieto at 10 am Having got aboard I also found present Col Ryan. Bean the War Correspondent Major Austin & many others. Col Ryan said he would come to the Chemist with me which he did & to my surprise altered the Requisition & ordered some nail brushes for his own ship & also some drug that I was getting & that after sternly refusing to let me have anything the night before

We got to Albany through the inner Harbour which is very spacious & very well protected from the weather How Freemantle came to be chosen before it the Politicians alone can say

Albany is a pretty place & has quite modern buildings & very good roads After doing our business at the Chemist Col Ryan asked me to walk out to the Fort with him as he had some business there.

We set out & I found the old chap very decent & interesting & also very fond of wild flowers He was continually roaming off into the bush looking at some new Flower. Arrived at the Fort we got a beautiful view of the fleet lying at Anchor in the outer Harbour & as it was a clear day with a cloudless sky the scenery of the surrounding country & the deep blue of the water & all the transports was a wonderful sight I left the old chap shortly before lunch & then met Major Millard of our Ambulance

He & I had plenty to talk about & had lunch together at the Freemasons Holet an excellent place

Afterwards I left him finished my shopping & then went to the wharf & got on the tug boat which was going around the fleet.

Here also were many other officers & also the Captain of our Ship.

After visiting the Flagship we went to the Euripides where I saw Lt Col Newmarch. Then to the Argyllshire where I saw & yarned to Archie Aspinall & Clem Marshall Both looking well

We eventually reached Star of Victoria at 6 pm & glad to get back I was. It is easy to get off the boat but with the irregular boat service I thought I was never going to get back
Entry.12:
At 6 am we weighed anchor & proceeded into the inner 

Harbour where we anchored & took on fresh water

While in there HMS Minotaur passed us while we saluted & they responded

During the Afternoon the SMO decided that White (Trooper) was too sick to stop on board so he was sent ashore during the afternoon It was thought he had Typhoid I took him off to Shore We were sorry to see him go but it was the best thing to do for the poor chap

Coming back to the Ship we looked about for the Motor boat which had towed the Ships boat to the Shore but could not find her.

In desperation we hailed a Naval Pinnace who were decent enough to tow us out.

Captain of the Star was much amused 

at this as he said they would never have done it in times of Peace

Aboard once more we steamed out of the Inner Harbour to our Station in the Outer Harbour to be ready for Sea the following day

How the troops cheered & cooeed the people on the shore as we went out It was to be their last glimpse of people on Australian Shores for many a day
Entry.13:
At 6 am the Fleet started on the move. It was a great sight to see all the boats slowly move out manoeuvre outside into position

This took some hrs & the position we finally took up was in 3 11 lines with from ¼ - ½ mile between the ships & a mile or mile & ½ between the lines On either flank was a Warship. One in front & one behind

During the 1st day the going was slow as the ships were continually slowing up on account of being unaccustomed to this new order of things The New Zealanders at night formed up into independent lines to the rear of the Australians

At night with all the Mast Lights Side lights shewing one could imagine oneself back in Sydney Harbour again.
Entry.14:
Routine as usual Horses all seem to be suffering from colds up to date we have lost five

Influenza Epidemic still continues Weather is Keeping beautifully fine although sea is choppy & the vessell is rolling a great deal Did not sleep well last night on account of rolling.

Sunday night Cocos Islands / Monday morning 

Monday. Naval Engagement
Entry.15:
Influenza still severe Hospital full. Ships are keeping better in line now.

Wednesday had a meeting of officers when it was decided to hold a Sports gathering for the men on Saturday A Committee formed Also decided that they should have a concert in the evening. Still have about 30 patients in Hospital.

Am finding iti difficult to fill in all the days & will be glad to see the land again. Spend many a pleasant hour yarning to S.M.O.F. Fullerton who is full of a quaint humour tells a story excellently & is altogether a very decent Colleague to have on board.

We have an Appendicitis case on board which is now quietening down At
Entry.16:
he was very acute & in my opinion should have been opened as I thought the risk of perforation great

However, S.M.O. thought we had better wait. Now the mans better & naturally the S M O is pleased So am I as I would not relish the idea of an operation case on board this ship as the Horses are all over the place & the conveniences for operation crude.

For instance to get an Operation theatre we would have to turn out of the top ward the acute Influenza cases & operate there nice clean place eh. One at such times longs for the Main Theatre S.H. & Sister Marshall This case emphasises the differences both between the young & the old Practitioner & also between the G.P. & the man brought up in a Hospital. I am very much inclined to & admire the diffidence of the G.P. in not rushing headlong into operative procedure. All the same in this particular case I do think an unjustifiable risk 

was taken
Entry.17:
Routine much excitement all afternoon as away in the Horizon was seen coming towards up with us what appeared to be a Mail Steamer

Later on about 6.15 pm we all rushed up on Deck to/with the sound of the Troops cheering the band playing on the boat deck.

What a sight it was & how it brought home Australia and Home back to one at once There was that fine Orient boat the Osterley passing us on our Starboard bow & only about ¼ mile away.

The Decks were lined with people who cheered & cheered &waved flags & anything else they could get hold & how lustily our troops & officers cheered & waved in return

They were good enough to Semaphore to us the result of the Melbourne Cup which we were eagerly waiting

as we had a Sweep on the same Of course we cooeed & they also To think that in Sydney Harbour we would pass such a boat any day & never take any notice of her But it is different out on this wide Ocean Anything new or ships from Home is intensely welcomed I daresay the Osterley had plenty to talk about that night after having actually seen the Troop ships all together & being escorted by their warships
Entry.18: Routine as usual Influenza Epidemic about same We are averaging about 240-257 miles per diem & are now into the Tropics & it is getting decidedly warmer We have a very light S.E. following wind just strong enough to temper the heat. The Energy in the pursuit of Exercise by everyone is abating & also that feeling of well being
Entry.19:
Paddys Hurricane

that cold bracing weather engenders

Saturday. Much speculation this morning H.M.S. Minotaur passed down through the lines & steamed away to the South Is she going after the Emden people asked as we are now in the Emdens Happy Hunting ground. Any rate she appears to have gone for good

During Saturday afternoon Sports were held on the Boat Deck & the tug of wars held between the different troops were greatly appreciated & the Sack races were also wildly cheered Some of the contestants were too eager & now there are three of them with very swollen toes sprained during the Sack race

Stables at 4 pm ended this meeting after the Officers had had a tug of war in which side I happened to be on won after 2 prodigious struggles

We felt just done up after it. Especially myself as I then had the Influenza in just sufficiently a severe form to produce pains & aching all over

During the evening the men held a concert at which there was considerable talent displayed by the different artists Alphonse Spagoni appeared to be the most popular item on the programme At 8 pm we had Boat drill at which when the alarm sounded we all quietly got to our allotted posts with Lifebelts on & boots & socks off. The whole lot of the ships were then kept in complete darkness for an hour.
Entry.20:
During morning Wireless got it that there had been a death on board Euripides.

Euripides at 10.30 am pulled out of line to Starboard side & there was a burial at sea Pte Kendall Infantry

all Ships meantime flags at half mast One feels something repulsive & uncanny about the idea of a poor fellow being consigned to the Deep

We have not been told what the cause of Death was. I would like to know very much.

Sunday Afternoon sultry & muggy weather a Mock Court Martial was held on Captain Reid This promised to be rather amusing at the beginning with Capt Lawry who has a keen sense of humour as president.

However the O.C. turned up & insisted on the thing being done formally for the purposes of instruction forsooth As a result it was a most boring affair as OC acted as a wet blanket & did not even know the correct procedure himself

This gentleman is rather a tiresome sort of individual He hails from

a small Country village in N S W Raymond terrace where as the only Medico in the place He is apparently a small Tyrant. S.M.O. has christened him the Rustic Bull or in dog Latin Taurus Ruralis

He is suffering I am afraid from a severe attack of Swollen head & is always trying to impose petty restrictions For a couple of nights E G he turned up at Dinner in a white coat, then when a couple of officers followed suit they were severely reprimanded for not being in proper Mess Dress I notice since he has been turning up in proper mess Dress himself I hear that while the Regiment was in camp he slept about 2 nights in camp & never once handled the regiment himself in the Field I hear also that the Powers that be know all these interesting

facts so one may reasonably expect developments.

My attitude is one of studied amiability & politeness to the same gentleman & so consequently have not run foul of him at all as yet.
Entry.21:
At about 5 am this day we passed abrest & to the west of the Cocos Island some 60 miles At about 7 am the HMAS Sydney was noticed away to the rear leaving the Transports & steering East roughly & presumably (I did not see her) Little did we think what was in store At 12.00 md that day the news was flashed through from the "Sydney" that she had engaged the Enemy presumably the Emden & that the latter was now beached on Cocos Island in a sinking condition The Sydney was after engaged in chasing a Collier.

We had noticed about 10 am that the Jap Man of War steamed right across to the Melbourne which was on our Port side & that the two of them then went off at full speed but in ½ hrs time returned

How the Troops cheered when we got the news O how proud we felt of the "Sydney" & our Australian Navy that day. And how we thought of the news being flashed through to Sydney & of the consequent flaring Headlines in the Sydney Sun etc. & how we thought of the probable anxiety of people in Sydney many of whom we felt sure would think that a transport or two had been sunk

Then some wise fellow suggested that probably Sydney & Australia would not get the news for some time as it would probably disclose

the locality of the Australian transports Yes it was a great moment that when the news came through. One felt good to be alive & so proud of our little "Sydney".

It is thought that during Sunday night the Emden must have passed extremely close to us within 20 miles it is believed. What a harvest she might have got if she had got in amidst the ships under cover of night. Of course it would have meant certain destruction to her but some damage could certainly have been done before that happened

Monday Afternoon Euripides again hauled out of line & buried another man. There must be some serious condition on board; we have heard nothing.
Entry.22:
Stifling Heat today A detailed account of the Emden Debacle through today & appended by Courtesy of Wireless Operator Mr Pennington

Wireless Account

Sydney started for Cocos 7 am At 9:36 am she had sighted the enemy travelling at full speed She was able to get within range in 20 minutes. At the same time she signalled the chase was steering north At 10.45 am Sydney was engaging the Enemy briskly & at 11 10 am the latter had to beach herself to avoid sinking Her foremast & three Funnels were down but the flag was still flying Sydney then went after the Emdens Collier took the crew off & sank her Sydney returned again to Emden who surrendered Extent & nature of German Casualties are not yet known but are bound to be severe Sydneys own Casualties required Hospital treatment which was probably found on direction Island (Why not on the boat - Leslie). The Emden had had time to destroy the Wireless Station & cut one of the 3 cables A 2nd Cable is intact & possibly a third All Instruments except one were destroyed This had been buried & is now in use again. The Wireless & Cable Operators

deserve much praise for sticking to their posts & for saving instrument

Sydney will sail for Colombo as soon as she has succeeded in getting the German wounded & Prisoners aboard The operation may take 24 hrs as it presents considerable difficulty

Open letters plain postcards & urgent telegrams will be censored on board Orvieto for immediate dispatch provided all reference to ships places & dates are omitted Closed letters parcels will be delayed

The latter are instructions from the Flagship. Consequently it can be seen that letters will not be very enlightening as regards our where abouts or doings Leslie

Tuesday Afternoon. S.M.O. & I inoculated 120 men. Antityphoid. Later on 2 or 3 complained of headache & fever but majority suffered surprisingly little

We had been waiting for the Influenza Epidemic to subside but as it does not shew of any signs of doing so yet we thought we had better get the business over
Entry.23:
Not so hot today There is a slight head wind which is making conditions more pleasant. Sick Parades small today only 4 being admitted to Hospital with Influenza Another Dead horse today.

H.M.A.S. Sydney has not yet overtaken us She is I believe to go straight to Colombo with the German prisoners

Consequently the Transports are now escorted by 2 warships the Jap "Ibuki" & the Melbourne

Evidently the Indian Ocean is now 

considered comparatively safe

We are now sleeping out on Deck & find it very pleasant after the Stuffy & hot Cabins. The Day has passed slowly & monotonously. One even gets tired of reading. We are due at Colombo probably by Sunday or Monday morning That at any rate is something to look forward to.
Entry.24:
At 6 am the Jap & the Melbourne were close in on our starboard bow also the Orvieto. A boat passed from Melbourne to the Jap evidently some compliments being exchanged.

Later on Melbourne has it is reported left us & we are now attended by the Jap alone.
Entry.25:
afternoon 2 pm A Large gray ship 3 funnels a merchant cruiser it transpires passed us on our starboard bow. Most peculiar lines, the bows & stern of a cruiser.

She is I believe about 18000 tons. She was steaming south at a good rate & signalled "Good Luck Australia" as she passed

Seeing passing vessels on board is quite an event. Later it transpired she was the "Empress of Asia" & is bound for Cocos Island to take off the German prisoners & wounded We are near the line now & will cross it tomorrow morning

The weather is cool & showery a good strong N E wind blowing We are in the region what seafaring men term the Doldrums.

This is just on either side of the Line s & is characterised by heavy down pours of rain

Tonight Father Neptune came on board He is going to take toll tomorrow the Toll will be heavy.

He is one of the Troopers an old Sailor
Entry.26:
Today it is raining like Blazes & there does not seem to be a dry place on board

We now have another Cruiser with us the Hampshire a
Entry.27:
class cruiser I am told.

During the morning the N.Z. fleet steamed ahead full speed for Colombo escorted by this
Entry.28:
class cruiser.

They want to get to Colombo early as our stay is to be short & they have some repleniishing to do

During this morning there has been an upheaval Taurus Ruralis has discovered that an overcoat of one of the men has been apparently wilfully cut not a very big cut.

He is going to play H— with a big stick.

He has addressed all the men & as S.M.O. puts it, loud was the bellowing, 

Unless the man owns up He is going to stop all their Sports. All the money collected for their prizes is to be given to a sick & disabled Seamans Fund When they get to England they will have no leave for a month etc etc As a consequence Neptune has been forbidden to come on board & the men are all pretty wild about it
Entry.29:
pm All is peace again A man explained the whole thing The coat was torn at Rosebury getting over a fence & the piece torn was I understand cut off.

The remarks about the above gentleman are however I have heard pretty lurid down on the troop deck & his unpopularity certainly seems to have increased

How tactless & futile are these wild threatening speeches They never have the desired effect.

Father Neptunes ceremony as a consequence is postponed till tomorrow 2 pm

Have also heard that the Karoo has left full speed for Colombo today There is a rumour that she is on fire She has certainly it is said heaved 140 bags of fodder over board whether they are alight or not it is hard to say She is to be put out of the fleet at Colombo & her men put on other vessells The ship behind us the Oratara is said to have 90 cases on board in the Hospital of which 47 are Measles Also heard tonight that she is landing at Colombo. 7 cases of Phlbisis 1 of Cholecystitis & few others 2 or 3. What they are I have forgotten.

We are landing our Appendicitis case as we don’t want the risk of having to operate on him for a third attack at sea.

I am afraid he will be very disappointed.

Another man may have to be discharged for Specific trouble

The O.C. appears to be very reluctant about getting rid of the appendicitis case He asked me into his office after Dinner & asked me Did not I think that perhaps the man could stay

I had no two minds about it my opinion being that we dont want any burials at sea this trip & I think that would happen if we kept him. So the Medical opinion on the matter will prevail.

I really think there should be no questioning of our opinion in these matters & one would think that an O C who is himself a medico would have a little more Gumption

Tonight the rain has stopped & conditions are cool & pleasant Went to bed out on deck at 9 30 pm
Entry.30:
Fine & hot with Nor Easter, sick parades diminishing a good deal. Father Neptune to come on board at 2 pm At 1.40 pm Father Neptune arrived. There is a long bath of salt water fitted up on main deck just aft of boat deck Here the proverbial Father Neptune & his assts took toll. They doled out doses of such palatable stuff as sharks blood & plenty of Tc Iodine,

After the victim sat down he was lathered with paste of flour & water & then shaved with a wooden razor that finished he is given a dose of medicine which is just thrown on to his face & then he is tipped into the bath where 3 or 4 of Neptune’s assistants duck him Luckily I got a good footing when I was tipped in & managed to duck three before they got me

Nearly a riot. The O C commanded Neptunes Police to duck the Vet whom

he personally dislikes. Vet has been over the line before & consequently resisted. Other officers joined in & frustrated the attempt

The OC is even more unpopular now than he was before Very tactless. That night the men had a concert which was a welcome break to the monotony Tomorrow we will get to Colombo.
Entry.31:
6 am Land in sight again a welcome break after 14 days without seeing any land I can tell you a pretty country Ceylon with good sized mountains (compared to Australia) in its centre.

At 7 am commenced to see flocks of little Katamarans with their peculiar single square up Some got quite close to the transports & we could see the niggers looking quite excited.

At 1 pm we arrived off Colombo & anchored in our line outside the break water. New Zealanders are inside the Harbour as also are some warships We can see a Russian man of war alongside our Japanese escort the Russian a peculiar looking boat with 5 huge funnels & the bridge very much forward to the bows The Sydney is also in the harbour & does not appear damaged at all Also I believe the Hampshire. Later on the Russian steamed out & took up position on the outside of the transports to guard us. So now all the allies but the French have given us a hand.

Colombo through the Glasses looks very picturesque. There appear to be some fine buildings. In particular the Galle Face Hotel a fine red brick building with I believe 500

rooms looks very inviting.

the Effect of the vivid green of the grass & varying shade trees & palm trees is very pretty.

I spotted plenty of motor cycles cars & Rickshaws as I looked

Also a dome of what I believe is a Hindoo temple shewing above the trees away to the East of the town added to the interest of scenery quite new to one who has not been out of Australia. 

Later During Dinner was talking about Col Ryan when speak of the Devil etc. in he walked.

He had come by tug & said he would take our appendicitis case on to Orvieto

&	there operate.

Also he would see what he could do with our drug list.

I had a talk to him after & he said he did not think anyone could 

get ashore.

At 10 pm his boat had not arrived so I lent him a pair of pyjamas & he decided to sleep on our boat. I went to bed about 1030 pm rather tired.
Entry.32:
6.30 am. Col Ryan departed his boat came around at 11.30 pm last night.

Lt. Col Meredith the Adjutant & Quarter master are going to the Orvieto Major Vernon & Capt Reid are going on shore. Lucky beggars.

A tug came along side at about 11 am. Watched with interest the jabbering natives especially when the troopers began throwing down pennies to them How they scrambled for them & with what grins they asked for me Truly the nigger is of a very inferior race. They looked like dogs after a bone the way they got after the pennies They even got some silver

coins & the Captain a pock marked old villian bagged a florin. I suppose they will have a fortune when they get back tonight

Lt Butler came on board from the Clan Macq. this morning. He wants excuse to go back home as his father to whom he had given power of Attorney has died

I do not see how the authorities can allow him to go. If he does go one of our men will have to go over to the Clan Macq

Had an idle day. also during the morning saw another Cruiser come in. the Yarmouth probably from the China Squadron. She looks pretty dirty & appears as if she has had a fairly long voyage.

Read all the afternoon, & spent rather a monotonous evening

those ashore have not arrived back yet. I understand we leave Colombo tomorrow, the sooner the better if they will not let us ashore

Heard another bit about the Emden It appears that The Wireless operater on Cocos saw her come in to the Harb our He at once sent a message "There is a strange man of war entering the Harbour" This was intercepted by the Sydney who at once proceeded to the place Also read some papers this evening the Germans appear to be gettng pushed back especially by the Russians It is reported they have made some Peace Overtures to the Russians which have been rejected.
Entry.33:
At 11 am this morning all the Transports with exception of fast Division (in which we are

left escorted by the Hampshire They are to steam 10 Knots & we are to leave at 7pm & steam about 12-13 Knots

About Lunch time naked (except for a loin cloth) savages came along side in canoes built of logs lashed together & rowed by bits of wood. They dived for coins & 2 of them climbed up to the Bridge & dived from there for three shillings. diving was poor They jabbered about for an hour or so One chap had only one arm & dived very well He has been working the visiting boats for years I heard from the Chief Engineer & is well known
Entry.34:
pm We left in single line formation escorted by the Jap Warship in order. Euripides (Flag Ship. Argyleshire, Shropshire, Afric.

Benalla Star of Rangatira, Star of Victoria, Oratarara, Omrah & Meltiades. Our manoevering into position was accompanied by a Flashlight from the mainland which kept revolving about our course for 2 3 hours after.

Today weather cool with N.E. Breeze Influenza Epidemic abating.

Have now started to sleep up on the Bridge Deck & find it very nice after the stench from the Horses one gets on the Promenade Deck.
Entry.36:
Knots, the Afric keeps dropping back & consequently keeps the whole lot back, the Chief Engineer is very scornful about her & evidently wishes her in a hotter place than this.

Afternoon We are forming into two lines parallel. On our Port 

bow is the line as follows Euripides Argyllshire, Shropshire, Afric & Benalla. Our line, Rangatira Star of Victoria, Oratarara Omrah Meltiades.

Sparks tells me we are to pick up 4 N Z boats & go on at a good speed for Aden Other boats are not in sight yet.

Weather comparatively cool & pleasant Life on board is getting rather monotonous & one sweats too much to take active exercise.

Jap Warship is steaming steadily ahead
Entry.37:
The other boats can be seen just on the Horizon this morning. The Afric is still giving a deal of trouble. Cannot keep up a 12½ Knot speed at all. I am sure all the ships are cursing her I know we are.

This evening we are just behind them. Instructions received that the Afric is to drop out & that the Ascanius is to take her place. Much rejoicing.

Later the Four N Z ships are now ahead & the Ascanius has taken up position We are going ahead well & are getting abreast of the main Fleet Life on board just about the same no improvement worth noting nothing exciting
Entry.39:
Woke up 5.30 am we are doing & have been doing as I heard later a good 13 Knots during the night Have just heard the Bridge ring down to the Engine Room to stop.

Went to investigate find our line is stopped also the Euripides. Looking away back 4 or 5 miles can be seen the remainder of the

other line About 7 am we got on the move again the jap is now steaming down the line to investigate At Breakfast we learnt that the Ascanius had collided with the Shropshire Extent of damage not known but it cannot be great as they are both coming along.

By the time we got going again the Slow fleet was almost up to us. However we gradually lost them & about nightfall they were practically out of sight astern

Nothing much doing on board the OC is getting steadily more unpopular He has taken a violent dislike to the Vet & is foolishly taking advantage of his position to shew it.

He is consequently alienating every

one. I find that to get up on the bridge deck all day after my work is done is the only place to get away from him.

Old S.M.O. was trying to persaude me to do some lecturing to assist him. As I am doing practically all the medical work of the ship it does not appeal to me so I told him I would not especially as it is by no means my duty.

It strikes me the more one takes on the more one is expected to do.
Entry.40:
Travelling well today At noon 24 hrs run 299 miles, nothing of interest in the morning. After Lunch Mens Sports held Potato races. Fighting with pillows on a swinging pole etc. no damage to life or limb. They all seem to enjoy these meetings very much it must be a welcome change

after Stables 3 times a day drill & lectures.

Weather still fine with a cool N.E. blowing.
Entry.42: officer sick am treating him & have put him off his watch.
Entry.43:
am The Captain will do it or part of it. Captain is a very decent man courteous & very considerate to his men

His hobby appears to be a Brazilian parrot which he is teaching to talk the Beast however appears to prefer whistling at present much to the Captains disgust who declares that a whistling parrot will never learn to talk.

Consequently if you want to get into the Captains black books go & whistle at the Parrot.
Entry.44:
Went to a Church parade as a matter of form this morning Glad to say it only lasts about 15 minutes.

Heard today that the Ascanius is more damaged that they think. She may be put out of the show at Aden or Suez. It is rumored that there is a 25 ft rent in her above the water line & they fear her encountering heavy weather
Entry.45: afternoon read & slept Sunday evening walked about 3 miles felt much better afterwards Went to bed about 9.0 pm.
Entry.47:
Up at 5.55 am. All boats in proper station & going well Land on the Port bow. very mountainous coast line.

Socotra Island. Inhabited by a hostile half arab half nigger lot I understand. The Mountains

must be 6 or 7000 ft high in parts.
Entry.49: Aden Have now got Influenza & am in bed. A bare desolate looking place
Entry.52:
In Red Sea very hot still in bed.

There is now a regrettable hiatus of 3 months in the Diary caused no doubt in the first place largely by the depression of spirits so common after Influenza & secondly by the excitement of living for the first time in ones life under Oriental conditions.

However I will endeavour to make out the dates & happenings thereon.
Entry.54:
arrived at Suez a picturesque

looking place here we anchored well out in the stream & waited very impatiently for Port Med Officer to clear us & also for the Search light that every ship has when going through the Canal. During the day other transports all filed in Saw old Bill Ray who on the Kalima which passed quite close to us. He has a moustache quite noticeable at the distance
Entry.55:
About 16 Indian Transports arrived this morning with Indian Imperial troops on board. Some very fine boats especially some Union Castle Boats with Red & black funnells Much cheering between Australians & Tommies, Cooees & Tipperary

Wednesday 2 pm started into the canal much joy. everybody sick of waiting.

I had forgotten to say that while in the Red Sea we had got notice that we were to finish training in Egypt. Everybody felt disappointed we did not know of good times in store

Much interest in the Canal shown the Boat goes very slowly so that there will not be a big wash Also a pilot is steering the ship through

We pass close to Suez & see the most beautiful clean streets. It appears to have been laid out by the Canal on model lines

Very clean streets with shade trees all along. Going along the Canal we see for the first time Camels & hooded women & the flowing garments everybody wears.

Also we see troops all along the Canal encamped

They have thrown up redoubts & made trenches & apparently have & are fortifying the Canal very strongly.

These troops are composed of English Territorials & Indians & many 

were the questions we got & answered Be you goin to Cairo said a Tommy. No, Berlin would answer an Australian & so on right along

There are wild rumers current that some of the first Transports that went through were sniped at by Turks from the Banks However we got through with nothing exciting to report & at 6 am Thursday 3rd we woke up & found ourselves at Port Said. Tremendous lot of shipping here & appears a very busy port no shore leave allowed. About midday, niggers came aboard to move coal. They appear to do a tremendous lot of talking. In fact they wildly gesticulated & talked for nearly an hour before they started work

In afternoon we heard we were to get

on the move again & after dinner about 8 pm we started out passing a French Warship on the way. We stood to attention & saluted as we went past, they responding with a very French sounding Hip Hip Hooray.

Friday 4th Land sighted & Alexandria as we left Sydney so we arrived at our destination in wet & miserable weather.

Entered the harbour about 10 am & anchored close to a coal wharf well in the harbour

Tremendous lot of vessels in this port Greek Russian Etc & many German prizes.

We are looking forward to 2 or 3 days wait about here as only 5 transports can unload at a time & to unload one appears to take quite a considerable time.

The work is greatly facilitated by the Railway running right on to the wharf & alongside the ships.

Saturday 5th

Some of us are going ashore this morning to have a look around. 

Diary of Gallipolli Campaign, till Aug 9th the day on which I was wounded 

Friday 2.4.15. About 7 pm. a few of us were sitting in a tent in the Ambulance lines when an urgent Dispatch arrived for which I signed. This declared all leave was off & that units were to be ready to move at a moments notice. We had been expecting this for days & days & when it came there was much rejoicing & bustling around to get things fixed up.
Entry.56:
We are to move off any time after 2 pm. today Already the big camp is being dismantled & spirits are high.

In the afternoon I took luggage in to store with Cooks in Cairo 2 tin trunks of my own & other stuff belonging to our officers, went in on the sidecar taking Hugh Poate who wished to say goodbye to his fiancee I called in there for afternoon tea & left shortly after tearing Poate away after some little trouble. We arrived back at the Camp just as the finishing touches were being put to the breaking up of Camp & had to bustle to get the sidecar stored away.

the onus of getting all things ready at the last moment seemed to have fallen on Aspinall who was directing things with his usual thoroughness. All the tents were down & stored in the waggons & just at the last all the rubbish was gathered into a huge pile & we had a very respectable bonfire on the site of a bathroom that I had made some time before out of a packing case & old mats & which was too much of an eyesore to leave on the about to be lonely desert.

The luggage I put in the waggons for my use in the campaign weighed about 70 lbs. (Regulations allow 35) & consisted of Coats 3 trousers 3 under pants 3 socks 4-5 pairs boots 2 pairs Hkerchiefs 6 undervests 3. rest made up of toilet gear various odds & ends & personal effects.

At 7.10 pm we got orders to get on the march. It was then already dark & the scene at Mena was an uninspiring one. There were huge bonfires leaving a dull red glow over the camp & the dust was thick in the air. All the roads out were packed with a jumble of troops on the march & transport waggons of every kind Nearly all the Infantry had left before us (the ASC leaving the night before & the road into Cairo was packed with traffic going both ways. I rode my horse in & I was glad to be on him as the marching was slow & there were many wayside halts owing to blocks & delays in the long columns on the way into Cairo. We arrived at the Cairo main station at 11 pm. & were then told that we had to wait till 2.50 am before any train would be ready.

However no one minded that & we camped on a grassy place just outside the station. Here all ranks were allowed to go off at intervals to get food & drink With Warsell I went to the Continental where the usual Saturday night dance was on & there we had supper. Managed to see Miss Knaggs & the Wells girls before leaving & said goodbye. We got back to the station & found that there were several merry souls among the unit all of whom had to be watched carefully lest in their exuberance they should stray off into the city & get lost. They had met friends with the inevitable result. However we got all of them on to the train about 3 am quickly & with no fuss & eventually left Cairo about am. everyone by that time being very quiet & sleepy.

At 11 am we arrived at Alexandria the train going right on to the Wharf. Here Kay met us as Embarkation Officer for the unit & directed us to our ship the S.S. City of Benares. 7000 tonnage. Transport A9.

Warsell left us & embarked on the Murvewaska with 27 men & 50 horses, the rest in our ship. I had a cabin to myself & was next door to Archie & Kay. Seemed a comfortable & clean boat. That evening Archie & I went into town & took ourselves to the Opera House where an Italian opera Coy were playing Rigoletto. The show started at 9.20 pm & ended well after midnight. It was very good all through & we thoroughly enjoyed it. The was a large & very enthusiastic Dago audience. We got back to the ship shortly after 1 am

5.4.15 Next morning we had very little to do so spent the time in watching some British Artillery disembarking near us.

They belonged to Ks army & appeared to be of better physique & sturdier than the Territorials of Cairo. We especially admired their huge draught horses which were bigger than anything we had seen previously in Australia.

Shortly after 5 pm we left the Harbour under sealed orders. Our OC. told us as we were leaving "confidentially old chap" that our destination was Smyrna at which I felt disgusted but soon after we were chaffing him about it as we were then issued with maps of Gallipolli Peninsula. Outside the boat pitched & rolled a great deal & caused a good many cases of mal de mer myself among the unfortunates.

The sea is rough & we are running into squally raining weather.

On Board besides 1st Fd Amb are the 1st Bde HQ staff, 3rd Coy. Engrs. (Major Cloughstorm who is also O.C. troops aboard. Our officers were asked to do general duty aboard ship but as we are a departmental Corps we did not see it in the same way as others protested against it effective

Calm & fine today we are now amongst the island that are so numerous in this sea. At 6 am we passed the island of Patmos of Biblical interest. St John was there at some time in his life.

After Bkfast all officers were called together to the Saloon where the O.C. troops issued instructions to us as regards our future work.

The Troops on board are divided into 3 eschelons. in A Eschelon is the 1st Fd Amb amongst others. This will be the 1st lot to go ashore in the landing on the peninsula.

The OC informed us that amongst other things of the important fact that water is very scarce on the peninsula so extraordinary precautions will have to be taken to guard against thirst

Every man is to be instructed that his Water bottle must be full & that he must drink himself full to overflowing before leaving the ship If he rejects any he is to fill himself up again It rather makes me think of the camels of Egypt. He is also to carry 2 days iron rations ashore which are to be issued at once. Anyone neglecting these orders is to be very severely dealt with.

We understand that we will probably have to fight for what water there is & even then it may be poisoned.

He jocularly asked if the medicoes would test the peninsula water by trying it on themselves but as one officer has a pet dog on board I thought it would be a good plan to let him have the first drink. Everyone thought it a good scheme except the owner.

Orders were also given about the water supply on board ship. It was limited & will have to be very strictly conserved as there is no condensing plant on board. We have had evidence of this already as we are only allowed about 1 quart to have a bath in every morning.

In the afternoon we came in sight of Lemnos & about 6 pm we entered the outer harbour & shortly after took a tortuous course through a mine field layed at the entrance & then entered the inner harbour This harbour is practically completely land locked & must afford great protection against the rough weather which is so prevalent at this time of the year in these parts. Away to the north maybe seen the mountainous island of Samothrace on which is a very high peak which is snow covered at the top. To the north again may be dimly seen Mt Athos on a narrow & long peninsula of the main land. This is the site of a famous monastery where 

for centuries no woman has ever set her foot. Lying in the inner harbour is a big gathering of every kind of vessel you could think of from the huge Queen Elizabeth & other warships English French & even a Russian cruiser the Askold which is an old friend to us. She lay outside the harbour at Colombo on guard over the transports of the 1st Aus Div when we came through. There are also transports , store ships minesweepers T B Ds; small Greek sailing craft. The Queen Elizabeth is a magnificent looking ship & makes an impressive show with her huge 15 in guns.

During the day we have been trying various ways of carrying our swags. We have decided on the swaggie’s method Blankets , W.P. sheets in a swag on one side balanced by iron rations on the other side Both bundles hang down in front are not tied on & so may be cast off at once if a man slipped while getting down the rope ladder into the boats.

Thursday. After breakfast we started practising the loading of the men into the boats. For this purpose. Each section was told off into two boatloads, each load about 30 men. Major Millard is in charge of the 1st boatload of our section while I have the second. I have discovered that I have some very good oars in my boat During the morning A9. was manoeuvred along side a sister transport ship & the two tied together This is being done all around the harbour the idea being to economise space as the harbour is now very congested.

My cabin now is on the side alongside the other ship & has become very stuffy as a result.

In the afternoon Millard & I took our boats for a row round the harbour. had a look at close quarters at the Russian ship. She looks old & indeed was in the Russo Japanese war from which she escaped intact.

Friday. Already there is a stench coming from between the two ships & the cabins on our side are very stuffy

In the afternoon we went out for another row & visited a Naval Hospital ship near by to us. We were shewn over her by one of the officers who was very decent & made us quite welcome.

The ship originally was a well known Indian Transport vessel. She carries 200 beds, seven surgeons & 40 ratings including some London St John Ambulance men.

There is a nice little operating theatre, well equipped carrying steriliser heated by electricity, also a very complete laundry 

Returning to our transport I took an oar & managed to work up a very good appetite for dinner. The food on our boat is good, plenty of it & well served. Everybody is well satisfied & the men have no complaints on this score at all.

Saturday, practising with the boats again nothing eventful, more transports & warships entered the harbour today. Every one is beginning to wonder when we shall move.

11.4.15 Sunday. With some other officers rowed over to the Derflinger this morning on which are the 2nd & 3rd Battalions. This boat is a German prize & was lying in Alexandria Harbour since the outbreak of the war. She is a very well fitted out boat & has a Gymnasium on board which is a revelation. All the apparatus is worked by electricity & amongst other things is a mechanical horse & camel which you can set to any pace.

& which give very lifelike imitations of the different gaits of these animals. In fact there is practically every kind of apparatus there & we had a great time trying everything. If only we had something like this on our ship a chap could keep fit very easily. We spent about 1 hr on the boat & had morning tea w some 3rd Bat officers one of whom was Street a son of Justice Street of Sydney & an old Pauls man. We then rowed to the Transport "Malda" where we saw Major Stokes of the 1st Fd Amb. On this ship is the 3rd Brigade H.Q. to which he is attached for a special duty. He has been at Lemnos since the beginning of March when the 3rd Brigade arrived here. Needless to say they are all very tired of the inaction. Stokes I think is not likely to return to the Fd Amb. we shall miss him. We brought him back with us to lunch on the A9 & then took him back to his ship in the afternoon.

Went ashore with Archie Aspinall & two officers from the ship (military) & as it was a beautiful fine spring morning we walked into Mudros which is a good three miles from where we landed. Mudros is a quaint higglepiggeldy village with narrow twisting & unpaved streeets Houses are all built of loose stones of varying size & colour cemented together. Everywhere I am glad to say scrupulous cleanliness prevailed a welcome contrast to the Egyptian villages which you can smell from afar off. "the characteristic odor of the East as it is somewhat romantically termed but which is really due to the accumulated filth of humans & animals for centuries.

When we entered the village we saw very few women & the ones that we did see were just like shy timid animals. As soon as they saw a soldier they would bolt for their lives not so the little children who would shyly smile at you & some of them were very pretty indeed with their big brown eyes & swarthy complexion.

Evidently these people judge all soldiers by the Turks. We went into a shop & after much haggling over exchange rates bought some chocolate & matches. The Islanders will take any English or French money but will not look at the Egyptian coinage except at a big discount. They are very fond of English gold.

Quite a number of the Islanders could speak English owing to the fact that many of them have been to different parts of the world. One we met who had worked in one of C....nes shops in Sydney. Taking the people alround & especially being fresh from Egypt they seem quite a decent type. On this Island there are said to be at the present time many Turkish spies In fact on all the main roads the British Authorities have guards posted whose duty it is to stop all people & examine their passes which are issued by our authorities. In fact as we were walking back to the boat we came across a batch of about 20 suspects, when the guards were bringing in a motley crowd some looking very frightened while others looked quite annoyed, but they all realised apparently that one cannot do much against fixed bayonets.

We have since been told that a week or so ago the guard brought in two women suspects & when they got into Mudros a crowd of about

40 women collected around the party & screeched & yelled their rage but to no purpose, the guard kept them well in hand.

We arrived back on board about 1 pm & felt quite tired after our walk. The worst of ship life is that it is too sedentary & you get out of condition very quickly. Took things easily in the afternoon. Looking around the harbour one sees a very impressive spectacle there must be by now over 100 vessels of all sorts & shapes in the harbour.

Tuesday 13th April the usual round the daily task we are getting bored. Military life seems to be so far nothing but stand fast carry on etc. Masterly inactivity in fact There are plenty of rumours but no information yet as to our projected move.

Wednesday. 14th April. This morning Millard, Aspinall & myself & few others took some patients to the shore hospital. We rowed right around to the Town Quay at Mudros left the boat there & took our patients to the Hospital which was situated on the hillside just beyond a French encampment & overlooking the harbour. We passed a good many French soldiers on the way who look very well in their new blue gray uniform Later on we also saw some of the Famous Foreign legion in the town They looked rather untidy & slovenly we thought. At the Hospital we handed over our patients & heard amongst other things that the Sanitation of the French units on shore was not good at all.

We then had a look around the town &

went over the Greek Church which is rather a fine looking stone building. Inside we noticed that there are no seats at all. whether the people stand or kneel all the time we did not find out. A quaint looking old Greek priest was inside & he had some mysterious game in hand; he burnt small tapers for every one from which he was supposed to predict things or something like that. We did not stop long after donating a coin to the church. We got back to the boat about lunch time & passed on our way across the harbour many boat loads of infantry. Everyday & all day the Infantry practise getting the soldiers ashore with their full equipment on & on shore may be seen soldiers everywhere, in battalions going for a route march or in smaller lots bent on exploring the Island. The fields on the Island are very pretty at present & in many places are bright with poppies. All the Island that we can see is very mountainous but the slopes seem very fertile & everywhere a green colour prevails. Up on the skyline of one ridge we can easily see from our boat a group of wind mills These are quite common the Island & as there seems to be always plenty of wind here one can understand their use. There is not a tree on the island.

Thursday 15.4.15 This morning our boat started to unload 1,000,000 rounds of

ammunition & has been at it all day. Mr Beers the Fid Amb Quatermaster is in charge. After dark the work went on all through the night by the aid of strong electric lights

The usual routine through the day. After dinner all the officers turned into the saloon & started censoring letters of which there is a tremendous pile.

The Censoring turned out to be a very amusing affair & was as good as a show. I will try & write down a few things we read. One man was writing to his mother & was telling her about the Queen Elizabeth, he stated among other things that he was told that she had recently been punctured, he evidently had worked in a bicycle shop.

Another man described part of his stay in Egypt as "while they were lousing at Mena" He evidently had suffered some unwelcome guests. Some of them called the censor bad names & one man started off & this was quite common by saying that as paper was scarce he would only write a few lines. He wrote 10 pages. Quite a number wrote with relish of coming horrors & one I read assured his poor old mother that "the Turks were very barbarious, they mutilate the wounded & often gorge your eyes out. This sort of 

stuff we find seems to be specially reserved for poor old mothers & sweethearts & in many cases we found was written by chaps who themselves had good safe jobs & who might never ever see a Turk.

Everyone on board is happy & fairly content, always there are rumors about when we go. Turkish atrocities etc The only smudge on the landscape is the awful smell coming from between the two boats. We are hoping that there will not be an epidemic of sore throats as we have had several already.

Friday 16.4.15. Today there are lighters along side & our boat is taking on a great deal of timber of varying lengths & sizes for the Engineers. This is a very important matter as we learn that on the peninsula there is only stunted scrub, as is common out here in the East. In fact both here & at Alexandria may be seen huge piles of firewood on the wharves which has been imported from outside countries.

Swimming in the harbour is very popular & nearly all the men on board go in for a dip in the middle of the day. Of course there are no sharks in these waters but even if there were I do not think it would make much difference.

Climate just now is perfect & is I am told just like that of Tasmania

Saturday 17th April Same routines & we are getting very sick of these rehearsals loading the boats etc & disembarking on a peaceful shore, everyone is longing for the real thing.

To make things worse our boat is getting the same old smell that developed on the Star of Victoria in the Tropics a vile smell due to stale ship air & horses & lack of a decent breeze, but it is no use grousing, it can’t be much longer. It seems a great pity that the horses cannot be taken ashore & exercised on land. They will knock up easily when their time comes after this confinement on board especially as it comes on top of the indifferent Egypt fodder. I took B section ashore in the morning & led them up a steep hillside to a hilltop commanding the whole harbour. When every one got their breath they discovered that it was a wonderful view as it certainly was. The harbour at our feet & packed with ships. In the afternoon I went ashore again with Millard Wassell & C Section. We marched out to the East coast of the island. On our way we passed through a very picturesque village where we pulled up & I took a

photograph of the section. The village is very primitive, the streets if you could call them such being simply formed by the spaces between rows of houses which seemed to have been built quite without any plan. But as in Mudros everything was scrupulously clean. On resuming our march we came across a number of girls & women washing their clothes at the Village washing Place of which I took a photograph. As soon as I got near enough to get the photograph all the little girls turned to the camera with a beaming smile while the elder girls & women covered their faces with their aprons. This is a most peculiar trait in these parts & I am told that the same thing occurs in Ireland where the women are also very modest. After leaving the village we climbed up on to a plateau overlooking the sea on one side & the harbour on the other. Up here the fields are wonderfully green & very pretty Many varieties of flowers may be seen in a wild state Daisies, blue bells, buttercups & even the homely Scotch thistle. Here we rested for a while & peered across the sea where may be seen in the dim distance the entrance to the Dardanelles. At any rate we decided it was & it coincided with the position off the islands Tenedos & Imbros that we have been studying on the map.

We returned the

way we came & that night slept the sleep of the weary & the just.

Sunday 18th April We have some more sick for hospital so Archie & I took them ashore. On the beach we saw a Wireless Apparatus in full swing & I was quite interested to see that the Dynamos were worked by Douglas Motor cycle engines. This plant is also rehearsing & will play an important part during the landing They are going to transmit the ranges to the warships for their big gunfire. In the afternoon I slept while Poate & Welch visited the Q.E. or the Queen Lizzie as she is affectionately called. They came back with some wonderful tales about her. They told us that the huge 15" guns could be certain of getting on to a target with a margin of 12 ½ yds at about 12 or 15 miles range.

Monday 19th April I have received orders to change places with Wassell who is on the Minnewaska. He is to take his place on A9 so as to be ready to get off with the Bearers of B section of which he is in charge. I am to stay on the Minnewaska with the Tent subdivision & the plan is that the latter with all the transport of other units will not be disembarking until the landing is secured which will probably not be until the 2nd day. About 3 pm I left the City of Benares & proceeded to the Minnewaska where I took over from Wassell. I was rowed over along with Col Maclauren Lt Col Onslow Thompson Lt Col Newmarch who were all going over to the

Minnewaska for a pow wow with the Generals on the coming events The Minnewaska is a very big boat 15000 tons & before the war was a Transatlantic cattle boat. She has however very good accomodation for passengers. She can do 18 knots comfortably. I found Wassell in a very comfortable cabin which I took over very readily He then took me down & shewed me the horses (50) who are all in fairly good condition except his own horse which has a nasty septic bite on the shoulder. This he got by fighting with Col Newmarches Arab pony who is a very crossgrained brute. In fact at present he has been placed by himself away from the others, he is so quarrellsome. My old neddie is looking splendid Sgt Poole sees that they get plenty of exercise every day & our unit is the only one to regularly take down the partitions & walk the horses around. Poole is very scornful about the way a certain English unit is looking after a few horses. They certainly look as if they have not been groomed for days. We have 27 Transport details looking after our horses & they are all good workers.

I then had a tour of inspection of the boat with Wassell & learnt who was on Board.

There are Gen Birdwood & Anzac Army Corps. H.Q. staff, Gen Bridges & 1st Aust Div.

H.Q. staff, two other Brigadier Generals. Col Howse AAMC 1st Battalion Some Army Service Army Post office & others I do not know. Looking up my exact details I find I have 48 horses, 27 Transport details, A Section Transport & all the water carts of the unit (3 in no). After dinner I met several Inf. officers I knew Carter (Tusky) Champion & Thompson M.O. I heard some funny tales that night in the Smoking room. One tale was that the Naval Authorities had intercepted a boat coming into Lemnos which had 260 riff raff women from Constantinople, Another tale was about a Turkish newspaper. It printed an article about the Australians & amongst other things said that. The Australians had to be driven out of Cairo at the point of the bayonet as they were so fond of wine, women & song, that they were extraordinarily good fighters & were a wild long bearded lot of Black savages. We do hope that the Turks will not be disappointed with their fighting propensities at any rate. I also heard it stated on good authority from the Naval men that one day last week just at dawn a Taube was observed overhead but it did not stay long, it evidently

came over for scouting purposes.

Tuesday 20th There is great secrecy on this boat & reliable information about the future scanty It is common property that the Landing is expected to be a difficult & ticklish job, that the Turks are supposed to have at least 70,000 men on the Peninsula, are very strongly entrenched & have a great no of concealed batteries. It is rumored that 50 batteries have already been located. It is also said that the peninsula is guarded both by floating mines & by land mines.

It is thought that there will be landings attempted at 3 different portts in the Gulf of Saros under cover of the warships gun fire. Also rumored that a Naval Brigade will make a feint of landing farther up the peninsula. British, French, Australian & New Zealand & naval brigade troops to do the work exact nos I must not enter here.

In addition to the fleet at Lemnos there is also I hear another fleet at another island & it is common property that a great many Greeks are assembled here in little fishing boats who hope to have a finger in the pie if we are successful in getting on to the peninsula The weather has been beautifully calm the last few days.

Wednesday 21st A Wet & squally day. no chance of moving today as the sea is up. So rough.

did it get during the day that the Hymattus, a troopship was blown aground but is not in any danger.

Thursday 22nd April nothing doing & we are all sick of waiting. On Board Gen Birdwood is already very popular. He may be seen at any time of the day walking about among the troops & horses talking to them & listening to any complaints they might have. He talks & listens in the most simple & natural way possible & is voted a great fellow by our chaps. He inspires confidence in everyone at once. I am glad to say that I had a chance of a few words with him, nothing much, but enough to get a good look at him & appreciate him. Meeting a man like him makes you appreciate that he is the true type of Englishman & makes one feel more than ever the wish to see England & some more like him.

Friday 23rd April. Mysterious bustle & preparation on hand & everyone feels that the hour is now close at hand. About 5 pm our suspicions are confirmed.

Gen Birdwood & staff leave our boat & go off to a warship on which they go to the

peninsula. All the men & officers assemble on deck & three very hearty cheers are given for our General 8 pm. Gen. Bridges & staff go off to another warship. We again give them cheers. In addition during the afternoon 5 transports steam slowly out of the harbour amid a great scene, bands playing & on every hand side mighty cheers are to be heard from all the ships. All ranks now are as happy as larks we know now that it is only a matter of hours & we will have our first sight & taste of the real thing. It is great to think of it after all these weary months of waiting. To bed early as we expect to be off early in the morning.

Saturday 24*h April. Awake at 6 am & find that we are underway at last. We are already outside the harbour & are skirting the West coast of Lemnos. At am sight Mount Athos quite distinctly. Here is the famous monastery about which I have already written. Everyone is eager & expectant. At 10 am we anchor in a bay at the NE corner of Lemnos where already there are three other transports at anchor. Here we are to wait all day & proceed to Gallipolli late at night. The 1st Battn i s to go off early

tomorrow morning after the covering party have secured a landing. The honor in this falls to the 3rd Brigade under Col Maclagan. By evening there are 8 transports packed with troops in this bay. The Troops are all as unconcerned, laughing & joking as if they were on a huge pleasure cruise. The thought that strikes a Sydneysider is. Are they really going into battle tomorrow, or down Sydney Harbour for a Sunday outing. You would think the latter to look at them. One cannot be anything but cheerful & confident with such smiling & happy faces around Of course everyone I suppose has an under current of anxiety in their minds as to what will be the result of tomorrow It is inevitable that everyone is not coming out intact but we are in the real thing at last. I for one will not go ashore tomorrow so my baptism by fire is deferred for the present. For the first two days I play a tame part, will have to sit on the boat while the others are in the thick of it However who knows what will happen. Plans may have to be altered at a minutes notice Reveille is to be at 4 am tomorrow, needless to say there will be

no bugle blown. About 5 pm I sat on an upper deck & watched & listened to a large group of 1st Battalion boys down below I will put down a few "just before the battle sayings" that I heard. It serves as an illustration of their devil may care attitude.

Eh Bill said one burly gravel puncher as the Infantry are called at times. We are goin’ to ave a nice ‘ot breakfast tomorrow Yes, said the other, first I ‘eard of it. Yes said the first Bread & mustard. They had been just issued with fresh rolls for the mornings breakfast

Oh well said another, if the ammunition gives out tomorrow we will still have the biscuits, a lively satire on the hard iron ration biscuits of which every man is to carry two days supply off the boat. Personally I have been fairly busy all day & have not had much time to let my mind dwell on all that might happen.

One or two only I have seen who might be said to be somewhat nervy. One chap saw some suspicious looking boxes floating near the ship. I got quite excited, brought two or three others along & quizzed the things through glasses
