thought they might be mines possibly. However they were only empty packing cases. One’s mind somewhat naturally turns to mines. One little chap then assured me that at any rate a fellow cannot be too careful. I quite sympathised with his fears. Just about dusk we saw a stirring sight. Away to the west in the ghostly half light we caught a glimpse of four huge battleships in line steering towards the peninsula at full speed. It thrilled me to see these emblems of the might, majesty & power etc.

About 10 pm I have a yarn with Thompson the 1st Bn medico & we go over plans, ways & means for the last time He is a very cool customer & ought to do well for his unit. We hear that we are to sail about 11.30 pm & that at 3 am absolutely every light in the ship is to be put out. At 11 pm I went to bed to try & get a few hours sleep. In spite of the fact that I have a soft job tomorrow I feel quite as excited as if I were to go off among the first. Tomorrow ought with luck to be a red letter day in future Australian History Books.

Sunday 25*h April 1915 It is worth underlining. 4.20 am. I have only half slept after all, half hearing everything. Now can be heard people moving about & talking in low voices so I decide to go up on deck. Up on deck most of the officers are standing about It is starlight still but the dawn will soon be on us. The air is crisp & cold while the sea is like a mill pond. In the half light one can just make out that we are heading for a bay between Kaba Tepe & Nibrunesi point, steering practically dead east. The shore can be dimly made out. Straight in front about 2-3 miles away can be made out high ground going straight up from the beach. To the North there are also hills dominating the bay. We are getting closer & closer in & one cannot help thinking, When will the Turks open fire on the ships in the bay from these commanding heights which are in front & to the north of us. surely they must have big guns there & what about the torpedo tubes that the shore is supposed to be lined with in different parts. But they cannot have seen us. Now it is getting much easier to see & we are about 2 miles I should say from the shore. Big warships may be seen lying close into the shore & several transports seem to be almost on the shore so close are they in. Still no big guns are heard.

Now about a mile & ½ from the shore & continuous crackle of rifles can be heard plainly. The 3rd Brigade have landed. Now may be seen Destroyers flitting about while the mill pond sea is dotted with launches & row boats some single most in tow by naval stem pinneces in long snakelike columns.

Our ship A11 is now about one mile from the shore & our anchor rattles out as we slowly come to a stop.

4.45 am the 1st big gun of a warship that is close in roars out. The first that we fire in the battle said Bean the war correspondent as he looked at his watch & gave us the exact time Again the gun fires & we see that she is attending to Gaba Tepe. A shower of sparks go up & there is a low murmur of applause from the troops on the deck below. We can now plainly hear the crackle & the rattle of machine guns on shore. Still no big gun speaking fromthe Turks. We now see for the 1st time an example of the stern reality of war. Just to starboard of our boat is a row boat which has been cast off for the time being from a pinnece. In it are two sailors, one with a wounded arm & the blood staining his shirt is supporting a mate who is rolling on his seat only ½ conscious with a bullet wound in the head. Even to me a medico the first impression gained in cold

blood as we stand on deck doing nothing gives a sickening feeling just as I felt when I saw my first surgical operation as a student and I thought I had lost that feeling for the rest of time. The row boat has still way on & comes in alongside where willing hands get the poor chaps aboard & they are soon attended to & put to bed.

Just about 5.45 am an enemy shell falls & explodes in the water about 100 feet in front of the bows of our ship So I suppose we can now say that we have been under fire. Of course in a mild way compared to those on shore. We wonder how many more shells will come over Some more arrive but go wide of our ship.

6.15 am A TBD comes alongside & the 1st half of the 1st Battn swarm over the sides of the ship on to her iron decks. I then went down to attend to 12 wounded men who have arrived on the ship out of different landing boats. They are some of those who were shot before setting foot on the beach.

Down below I meet the commander of the T.B.D. who has come on board to find a medico to look at 15 or 16 wounded & dying men he has on his T.B.D. I spoke to Col Ryan & leave him & Lt Col Marshall to go on tending the wounded already on board while I went with the

Naval man down the rope ladder in to the T B.D. whose decks are being packed with 1st Battn troops. 400 this craft will carry. I find 3 severely wounded & moribund cases. (1 Fractured skull bullet wound & 2 abdominal bullet wounds). There is also another abdominal case in fairly good condition About 10 other cases there are less serious in nature. These wounded belong to the 3rd Brigade & to the naval men who were in charge of the landing boats. As the vibration & heat on a Destroyer are so considerable & as she will be packed with troops these wounded will have to go on to the Clan MacGilvray which is acting as Hospital ship. We manage to get a steam launch & with the help of the Jack Tars who are wonderfully good fellows we quickly get the wounded transferred I then turned round & made my way to the rope ladder & find that I just miss making a trip ashore. The TBD has already cast off from A11 & I have to jump for the rope ladder & chance a ducking.

By the time I got up on to the Minnewaska it was 7 am, the sun was shining brightly, the sea was perfectly calm & there was not a breath of wind. It was just like an

early Spring morning on Sydney Harbour or even say at Dee why beach.

I then went down to the wounded on board ship & with Col Ryan & Capt Lewers worked at this till 8 am & made them all comfortable for the time being. I saw they would need considerably more attention in a very short time as the wounds were bleeding, & which was difficult to check stright away. We then had some Breakfast & shortly after about 8.15 am, the second lot of the 1st Battalion went ashore by TB.D. Col Ryan & Lewers went with them & I was left the only Military medical officer on board.

A little before 9 am before going down to the wounded again I noticed a warship close in to shore which was slowly working down on to Gaba Tepe & absolutely plastering G.T. with terrific broadsides, the din & the explosions are magnificent to see, clouds of smoke dust & debris hurtling into the air. There is a well concealed battery here that is able to enfilade our landing place & so work great havoc. This battery is silenced shortly before 10 am but the warship has been at it since daybreak.

At the same time. Another big warship is

standing off the coast to the south of Gaba Tepe & firing broadsides inland at batteries concealed I fancy in a gully, well behind the ridges which our men are now contesting She is giving the place a hell of a time & goes on with her good work nearly until 12 m d The Turks are now firing a great deal of shrapnel which is bursting over our men as they are on the ridges as they are landing & even as they approach the shore in the open boats Shrapnel bursting leaves a puff of white smoke in the air just like a white cloud Our men as yet have no artillery ashore & are relying on the fleet guns. The firing on shore now is very heavy & continuous. Our poor chaps must be suffering heavy casualties.

About 9 am I went down to see the wounded & from the less serious cases heard a little about the landing of the 3rd Brigade. The men just tumbled out of the boats almost before they were ashore waded ashore & without waiting for orders charged up the hill which here rises sheer from the narrow beach. They dislodged the Turks with the bayonet with an impetuous rush & soon had them flying. As it happened our landing was made further to the North

than was intended but it proved a blessing in disguise as the Turks evidently did not expect us at this point for it was found to be more in the nature of an outpost. Consequently we more or less caught them napping & by the time they had rushed ample reinforcements up from Gaba Tepe our men had secured a good footing on the shore. I spoke to a sailer who had nothing but the warmest praise for our men. He said it was magnificent to see how cool the men were, & how they rushed this first ridge.

On inspecting the wounded I found that I would have to dress the majority again, as the bleeding was so troublesome. I had just started when we heard the roar of shells through the air & three dropped alongside us in quick succession exploding with a most vigorous bang. One just missed a Destroyer that was near us, another fell about 50 ft from us & the last a little further away. Presently up came the anchor with a great rattle & we quietly steamed out to a point about 3 miles from the shore. Two of the wounded I find have died. One a naval man & the other an A.M.C. man belonging to the 3rd Brigade. I find there are two other AM.C. among the wounded.

The majority of the wounded were hit

about the knees & legs. Evidently they were hit as they were sitting in the boat in a crouched up position

The wounds are all large & irregular jagged holes with free venous haemorrhage & I find that packing the wounds with gauze is most effective. One bullet I removed from the knee of a Jack Tar. It was just under the skin & was mushroomed out into an extraordinary shape. He was very proud of it. Most of the men are suffering a good deal from shock, largely due to the reaction after such tense excitement that they experienced However they are all very happy & proud of themselves & their mates, are ready to put up with any pain & inconvenience & are talking nineteen to the Dozen. One chap told me that our men went with a grand rush, but are suffering a great deal from snipers, who are hidden everywhere & are considerably helped by the dense scrub. He told me that our men are not giving any quarter as at present they have no time to take prisoners. I repeat it for what it is worth.

One poor fellow I have had a great deal of trouble with. His jaw is shattered &

bleeding into the mouth. I dressed him 3 times before 12 md before I could get it under control. He bore the pain which must have been hellish without a murmur & thanked me so gratefully when it was finished. I then gave him Morphia & at 12 md he was fast asleep. By that time I had fixed them all up & went up on deck again. I will never forget the scene. A thick haze of dust & smoke is hanging over the shore, the small white clouds are hanging overhead (shrapnel bursts) & the roar & rattle of machine guns, & rifles is incessant. Add to that every now & then the earsplitting roar of the men of war as they delivered terrific broadsides, the bayonets flashing in the sun as troops went over a ridge & you have but a poor picture of the scene. It was really beyond my powers of description At 12.30 I got orders to transfer all my wounded to the Hospital ship & by 1.45 pm I had got the last over the side on to a Trawler that was to take them over. Only a few out of the 16 were able to walk on. the majority had to be slung over the side on stretchers I must say a word of praise for Padre.

Green who gave me invaluable assistance He took all the names & particulars of the wounded & worked like a Trojan. My A.M.C. assistants were all Transport men of the 1st Fd Amb & their excellent work surprised me. In Mena Camp they never had much chance to learn much 1st Aid as they had to be continually with the horses, but they all, especially Sgt Poole turned to magnificently. They were indispensable.

1.45 pm. I had lunch or rather several if you judge by the amount I stowed away.

2.10 pm Our men are now well on to the ridge which runs in a N.E. direction from Gaba Tepe & from stray bits of news, going strong, but we hear the casualties are heavy.

Suddenly a warship that is lying quite near to us opened fire on to a ridge to the left & a little inland from the landing. We could see the bursts but could not make out what the target was, but heard afterwards that it was Turkish reinforcements attempting a flanking movement on the left. There was great slaughter we heard. The warship kept very attentively at this target for two hours much to our joy.

The Shrapnel may now be seen dropping continuously on our troops; there must be some well hidden batteries inland but it must be very hard to get direct fire on to them as the peninsula is nothing but a jumble up of hills & valleys in a most irregular formation.

4 pm We again get under way & proceed to Imbros 12 miles from Gaba Tepe & about the same distance from the entrance to the straight straits Here we anchor in a bay with several other transports, feeling very disappointed that we are moved so far out & not knowing when we will get our chance to get into the thick of things But the panoramic view we gained was some consolation for the time being, it was superb. We now can view all the operations in one big panoramic view picture. We can see the entrance to the straits & the peninsula stretching up to Gaba Tepe & beyond that again to Suvlabay & then on into the head of the Gulf of Saros. Off the entrance may be seen a big flotilla of warships & transports & further down off the Asiatic coast may be seen another lot which belong to the French. Here they are probably making a feint at landing. Among the former flotilla is the Q Elizabeth & she is now firing at Achi Baba. This hill she is

pounding with broadsides & it looks just as if it were a volcano. It seems to one as if she must knock the Top right off the map. At this point, the Tip of the peninsula, the English are attempting a landing. All along the peninsula can be seen the battle haze which is very like the dirty pall that hangs over Sydney on a still day

The day has been perfect, a brilliant Spring day practically no wind & the water as smooth as glass From a weather point of view it is one of the finest Sundays I have known, but who would have thought it Sunday.

They say that modern warfare is not at all spectacular but as viewed from the decks of a liner this battle is a most spectacular affair. Why at Gaba Tepe we could even see the glint of the bayonets. Just before we left that point the Indian Mountain batteries were being got ashore & a little after 2 pm they were disembarking some of the Australian Field Batteries. They will have plenty to do I should think dealing with those parts that the warships cannot touch on account of the flat trajectory of their gun fire As yet there are no other mounted units ashore and I suppose we will not disembark for

at least two days. I don’t know why they do not get the Tent subdivs of the Ambulance ashore today, surely we could do a good deal ashore.

6.30 pm A sudden call to proceed full speed to Gaba Tepe. We are to act as a Hospital ship. With the help of the Amb men I at once got all the available medical stores out of the hold & started getting the ship into order so that it would be something like a Hospital ship. There was plenty to do & I am the only military med officer aboard. The Ships Doctor a very decent old chap has offered all his stores & his services unreservedly.

But we had only gone about 3 miles when we turn round & went back to Imbros, a false alarm. We were keenly disappointed as on board here we have nothing to do & it makes one feel rather small when you think of all the chaps out in the thick of it, hungry, probably thirsty & dog tired while we are on board. 1st class passengers on a Transatlantic liner. I feel disgusted with our lot. But at any rate I had a heavy mornings work from 7 am till after 1 pm so that makes up a little I suppose.

After dinner we went up on deck & could hear the firing as plainly as ever. We could

also see the flashes of shells & of signal lamps on the hills.

Went to bed at 9.30 pm dog tired after the most exciting & thrilling day of my life. But how much more tired must those brave chaps on shore be.

Col Howse is ashore with a detachment of the Clearing Hosp. who are doing the work that I thought the Field Ambs. would be doing.

Monday 26th April Another perfect day clear calm. We can see plainly the Australian & N Z transports & warships off Gaba Tepe. while off the entrance & further down there is a large no of vessels & signs of great activity. There is a violent bombardment of the point of the peninsula all the morning & huge clouds of smoke & dirt go up as the warships shells take effect. Here the British are landing. We do not know yet whether they have successfully landed as a whole or only in part.

11.30 am The Q.E. suddenly steams full speed up the coast towards Gaba Tepe. her speed is wonderful. A little after midday we can see her in position near Kaba Tepe & she has begun a most violent bombardment of a conical peak which is inland & somewhat to the north of the left of the ridge the Australians are holding. This

peak appears to be at the end of a plateau, at the other end of which appears a rounded eminence & at this end appears what looks like a solitary tree on the plateau.

 	Sugar loaf 	Plateau 	Conical peak

We cannot decide the exact location of these features on the map so I cannot put a name to them.

Dense clouds are rising up from the peak & at intevals the whole peak is blotted out by the smoke. At other times it looks as if it were a smoking volcano. The QE is also shelling the length of the plateau.

We took the time from the flash of the guns to the instant the sound reached us, & we found it was exactly one (1) minute. Calculating on sound travelling 1100 ft per second, we find this makes us 12.5 m. distant, which is correct according to the Ship people. Later in the afternoon we could see a great amount of Shrapnel bursting over the ridge on which our chaps are & also over the beach. At first it looked as if our men must have fallen back but I suppose the Turks are systematically shelling the whole area occupied by us. Some bigger shells of the Turks we can see dropping in the water, evidently they are going for the shipping.

At 5 pm we get a little news which is very welcome. "The Australians are holding their own with the Turks falling back on the left wing Down South the violent bombardment continues the whole afternoon.

just before dusk Transport vessels can be seen coming over the sea in single file & heading for the entrance to the Straits (6)

The night is comparatively quiet.

Tuesday 27th Another beautiful day with calm sea. We can see after Breakfast the Q.E. lying to below Kaba Tepe She is bombarding at long range the Achi Baba summit & range. She is delivering terrific broadsides & although she is quite 10-12 miles from us, the windows & walls of the smoke room are rattling & shaking as a result of the tremendous concussion. The sound is the loudest that we have yet heard I certainly would not care to be alongside the noble Queen Lizzie in her present mood.

Over the Australians position can be seen a very intense bombardment, both sides apparently being responsible. Some Turkish big guns in addition, are trying to get the Transports but their shells, which are making a lovely splash, are falling short. In a very short space of time however the transports moved

out of range, no damage done. About midday a serious accident occurred on our ship. One of the crew was in a lifeboat as it was suspended from the davits when suddenly the boat fell with a sickening crash on to the water 50 - 60 feet below. I actually saw the boat fall into the water & saw it smash like an eggshell & quickly ½ fill with water, but did not dream there was a man in it. However a sailer & a soldier quickly dived in & got the mans head out of the water, the poor chap was lying in the boat huddled up half in the water. The boat was then hauled up.

The ships Doctor & I fix the man up He is quite unconscious & has a factured skull, fractured arm & fractured thigh. He will only last a few hours so I left 2 AMC men to constantly watch him so that everything could be done for the poor fellow.

During the afternoon the British troops can be seen completing their landing operations, while ½ way between the point & Gaba Tepe a no of transports may be seen which are said to belong to the Aust & NZ Division.

During the afternoon Padre Green who is just as sick of this inaction on board ship as we 

all are, went off to a Trawler that has just come into the bay, & came back with some welcome news, even though it was a bit vague. The Australians have done splendidly & have done all that was expected of them in a much shorter time than was thought possible. Their casualties are heavy but not as heavy as might have been expected considering what they have achieved. Further the South end of the peninsula is now clear for the English to advance. The French are said to be reinforcing the Australians & all the shrapnel that we have been rather anxiously looking at during the morning as it was falling on the Aust position & about it is we hear mostly our own.

The Turks are entrenched around the Northern part of the ridge & they are the recipients of all this gun fire. This bombardment continues without ceasing till 10 pm. & the flashing of the shells as they explode makes a magnificent display in the darkness. Just inland to our position can be seen two bright glares, as if some stores or ammunition or even a village had been set afire. We have not received any orders to disembark yet & everyone is

feeling fed up. It is said that the landing place is still under a very heavy fire & this I believe is preventing the landing of Transports, Mounted units & Ambulance sections. It seems humiliating to be loafing about as 1st class passengers on a Transatlantic liner while our fellows are over there in the thick of it, constantly exposed to a deadly shrapnel fire, dog tired, hungry & thirsty. There is one consolation, there are plenty more in the same box as we are, why I doubt if all the Artillery is ashore yet.

The Turks appear to be putting up a very fierce resistance & our main task is very far from being easy. The enemy batteries in particular are giving our men a bad time & the warships are finding it very difficult to silence them, as they have all the advantage in this awful broken country.

From a weather point of view we have been particularly favoured & there has not been a hitch in the landing operations as a result. Every afternoon thick white clouds come up in the North East & remind me very much of those that come over Sydney from the N.W. on a warm summer day when a NE wind is blowing. Today these clouds worked up into a squally

rain storm & we saw that a great deal of rain fell over Gaba Tepe. However the storm quickly passed & now at 8 pm. the sky is clear & the air quite cool This Climate at this time of the year’s certainly ideal & reminds one very much of New S.W. climate.

At 9 pm. the accident case died He will be buried at sea tomorrow.

Wednesday 28th April. At last we are on the move We got orders to proceed to Kaba Tepe & arrive there shortly after 9 am. I am determined by hook or by crook to get off this vessel, and chance my luck with the ADMS on shore. I feel I cannot stick this sort of existence any longer My chance came sooner than I thought Just before lunch a message came aboard for me from the ADMS. He wishes me to send off all the stretchers I have on board as well as some reserve medical stores; as regards myself not a word, so strictly speaking I suppose I should obey orders & stay on board, but — Those stretchers & stores cannot be allowed ashore without a chaperon & I am going to be the chaperon & chance a wigging I feel very pleased with my chances.

I decide that it would look too suspicious to take my baggage ashore so I put my tooth brush in my pocket & a few hkerchiefs & socks in a haversack, my overcoat over my shoulder & leave all the rest of my gear on board, as, if I can stay on shore, I can easily slip out to the boat later & get them.

I left the A11 about 2 pm. after telling Sgt Poole to carry on if I do not come back & instructing my batman to look after my baggage.

I went ashore in a naval pinnece with a very small & unconcerned middy in charge. When we got within a mile of the shore we could see & hear the bullets dropping into the sea all around us but luckily no shrapnel came near us. I felt I did not trouble about them much & I think my secure feeling in this respect was due to the matter of fact air of the crew of the pinnece. You would think that they had been at such work all their lives. We arrive at a temporary Jetty a liittle after 2 pm. under cover of the ridge which at this part goes straight up from the beach & affords a good measure of protection against fire coming from inland but not against fire from the flanks. However, the batteries

on the right flank have been silenced so there is nothing to worry about from that quarter. The beach & the hill side present an extraordinary scene appearance. Stores, ammunition, kits, clothing are lying scattered on the beach while the hillside is swarming with Khaki figures, some of them digging roads, some digging dug outs, others hurrying up the hill & over the top with Stores or munitions for the firing line. I was immediately impressed by three things about the men & officers. They were all very sunburnt, very dirty & very cheerful. One might be on a big railway construction camp. Some of them are working stripped to the waist, & others are enjoying a dip in the water quite regardless of shells or bullets that come over. I soon found Wassell, Kay & Major Stokes who were sitting in a dug out half way up the hill. They are very cheerful & tell me a few of their experiences during the last few days. From all accounts the first day ashore was a nightmare During the afternoon the wounded came pouring down on to the beach till it was packed to overflowing, and it was not till late on Monday afternoon that the beach was at all clear

of wounded.

Then at midnight on Sunday night or a little after an order was passed to all the troops on the beach to fall in & be ready for re-embarkation The Navy it is said had received an order to send boats ashore for this purpose & the troops were actually on the point of reembarking when the whole thing was discovered to be a mistake. The 1st Fd Amb men on the beach had actually fallen in. Indeed during that Sunday night it was touch & go, our line was very thin, & it is said that on account of the heavy casualties the Generals held a conference late on Sunday night to decide on sticking to what they had got or getting off. Wassell & Kay have had a very strenous time, but by now the work of collecting the wounded has been put in order & each Fd Amb has had a definite area allotted. Our Amb. is collecting up a valley on the right flank & Welch is at present up there on duty. Wassell is going out after tea. The 1st Fd Amb has had 5 or 6 men wounded & Capt Webb has been hit in the thumb by shrapnel It is not serious enough to go off duty. Capt Bean AMC 3rd Bn has been wounded seriously & has gone off to a Hospital ship. Other medicoes have been

hit & three of the Battalions are at present -S Medical officers. The 3rd Fd Amb. had about 30 SB’s out of 100 hit on the first day. Their casualties occurred chiefly as they were coming ashore with the 3rd Brigade. About 3 pm. I found Col Howse ADMS. 1st Aus Div. & reported that I had brought ashore stores & stretchers. He appeared to "tumble" to my little game straight away for all he said was I don’t suppose you can get a boat back to your ship tonight. I said No sir I am afraid that is impossible. He then asked me if I would like to take on a battalion, to which I very gladly said yes. so he gave me the 3rd Battalion.

I then returned to the 1st Fd Amb. & found that they had been moved about ¼ mile down the beach where I ultimately find them. On my way down I pass great nos of mules led by Indians These are carrying water & stores up the valleys to the Troops. I also passed a wireless apparatus on the beach which is transmitting messages to the warships.

I find that my best plan will be to go up

with the 3rd Fd Amb Stretcher Bearers after tea. They are working the valley where the 3rd Battn are posted & of course know exactly where the Battalion Aid post is.

I had some tea at 6 pm consisting of Bully Beef, Hard army biscuits just like dog biscuits & tea. Was very hungry & enjoyed it thoroughly About 7 pm I went back to the landing place & there met some 3rd Fd Amb S Bs. who directed me to Capt Conrick AMC who was to go up with them that evening. I was very glad to meet him as I would have surely got lost if I had tried to find the Battalion in the dark by myself.

A little after 7 pm. we started off just as it was getting dark, passed over the 1st ridge at the landing place down the other side into what was named Shrapnel valley. We kept up this valley for about ¾ mile & needless to say I had much to look at on the way. What impressed me most was the huge amount of kits & clothing & toilet gear strewn on both sides of the valley. There must have been hundreds of pounds worth just lying where the men had cast them aside. For the country is so mountainous & rough that the troops

found that it was impossible to work with their heavy packs on so they just threw off everything they could. We arrived at a place where another track branched off to the left & here I found my 3rd Battalion AMC details. The Corporal & Lance Corporal are running the show, they have their main aid post at this point, while further up just under the top of the ridge a little way back from the firing line is an advanced post. I stop at the aid post & the Fd Amb people go on up the valley to the path that leads up to the trenches 

I find that the AMC men have made shallow dugouts in the steep hill that goes up on the left hand side of the path & that, to a great extent protects the aid post from gunfire. Here in the day time the AMC even have hot drinks, tea coffee & beef tea constantly ready & this has been greatly appreciated by the wounded. I find that we are very well stocked with surgical material, as one of the AMC men picked up a surgical kit down the path & as a result the 3rd Bn have now got more dressings than they started with

The Stretcher bearers both Regimental & Fd Amb have been carrying cases from the firing line to this post & from here they are carried to the Clearing Hospital by Fd Amb bearers only. When I arrived things were slack so I decided to wait for the AMC Corporal Malone, who will shew me round on top of the ridge. As I waited an AMC man passed leading a donkey on which was a wounded man. He is already a celebrity & is known as the Donkey man. He has been carrying cases down night & day without a rest since Sunday & goes up & down absolutely regardless of Snipers or shrapnel. It is said that the Donkey is one he found wandering about the shore when the landing was effected & he at once took possession. He is known all over Anzac by this. Anzac by the way is the name given to the piece of country we now hold & it is certainly very appropriate.

After waiting at the Aid post 1/2 hr. the Corporal had not turned up so I got one of the men to take me up to the advanced post, where I will probably find the Corporal.

We started off & got on to a zig zag path leading up the steep slope to the top of the ridge. This is very steep & slippery owing to the clay soil.

The moon is shining brightly & at several corners on the path I was warned to get down & half crawl along as some of these corners were enfiladed by Turkish snipers & during the day there had been several casualties on them. I met the Corporal at the Top station which is just below the crest of the ridge about 400 ft above sea level although only distant from the water about 900 yds as the crow flies. Here a hollow is scooped out on the top side of the narrow path & lying in this hollow are 4 bad cases, two just dying & 2 others very bad. I saw these two taken down by the Bearers & then I am invited by the Corporal to go into the firing Trenches with him. Personally I would have preferred to wait till morning as, listening to the bullets whizzing over, I felt a slight disinclination at the moment. However I could not let the Corporal go out without me so we started off. We climbed up almost vertically to the top of the ridge about 20 yds. up through sandy treacherous soil. On the crest the bullets seemed to be whistling unpleasantly close & we rested there a minute or two before running across 30 yds of open flat country.

which we had to traverse before getting to the Fire trench. The Corporal instructed me to follow him & we went across now crawling now doing short runs. The reason of this care was due to the fact that the Turks had machine guns trained on to this spot. We got across alright without disturbing any machine guns at all & I made my presence felt immediately in the trench by literally tumbling in on top of two men. I apologised but the men thought it a good joke. The Trench at this part was a poor apology for one as it was only about 2 ft 6 in deep with a small bank thrown up in front. The men as a result did not have much protection & had to kneel or lie down. What impressed me most was their extraordinary cheerfulness. There they were laughing & joking in low tones. One would never have thought that they had been there close on 90 hours without sleep & constantly on the watch. It was marvellous. I saw some wounded & gave directions about their removal. I saw a Sydney officer Lt Brodziak who had been lying out on an exposed dugout in the open for 36 hrs without attention. He could not be got at owing to the enemy fire. 

He was wounded through the neck, & was half delerious. The troops spoke very well of the AMC Corporal. They told me that he has been constantly in & out of the trench, tending the wounded & getting food & water to the troops He has been exposing himself with great bravery & according to the men bears a charmed life. After spending about 1/2 an hr in the trench I went back to the top of the ridge. Going back the moon was hidden behind a cloud so we got across without any trouble at all. Getting over the top of the ridge, the Turks suddenly began a furious rifle fire on our troops which lasted for an hour Everybody thought it meant an attack & we came to the conclusion that the Fire trench at that moment was no place for unarmed men. I stayed at the top aid post for an hour & as no more wounded were coming in I then went down into the valley.

Things were very quiet at the bottom aid post so I walked along the valley towards the left to see Thompson M.O. 1st Battn. I found him at home about 100 yds from my aid post & had a long yarn to him. Just close by him there is a spring to which he took me

for a drink of very good water. This was evidently a Turkish well. All around it now are a good many troops of different units in reserve. All the units I am told are hopelessly mixed up so that there will be a good deal of sorting out in the next few days. I went back to the Aid Post dug myself a shallow dugout & turn in to get a few hours sleep. My men found me a W Proof sheet & an old blanket & on there I lie covered with my overcoat. Just as I lay down it commenced to drizzle & as it was a bitterly cold night I did not get more than about 1/2 hrs sleep. I lay there with my feet feeling frozen & listened to the crack of the bullets. A peculiar thing about them is that although they are fired from a point about 400 yds away, they sounded as if the rifle was being fired off just above my head. Several times I would doze off & then wake with a start, thinking that there must be some Turks just above. Of course I did not know the country at all as I had arrived in the dark & so could not get my bearings.l As I lay there, I also wondered where the old blanket I was lying on had come from & whether it was lousy, frivolous thoughts one might say. We shall see later at any rate.

Thursday 29*h April Between 3.30 am & 4 am I got up & walked about to get warm. All the AMC men were asleep, being I suppose quite hardened after four days continuous work The sky was clear & the air very cold. About 4 am my batman started a fire & the billy. A little later we hear that the Battalion is relieved & that we are to be on the beach not later than 9 am. The whole 1st Brigade is to be relieved & a brigade of RMLI are to take their place. These

troops are actually now relieving our men & many 1st Brigade men pass down the valley on their way to the Beach & respite. They have been 4 days & 4 nights in the trenches without sleep & in the trenches that in many places can be scarcely termed trenches at all. Add to this the difficulty in getting water up to the firing lines, the rain & the cold weather & one can form some small idea of what they have gone through Their casualties too have been very heavy but their spirits are indomitable. About 5 am. we have breakfast at the Aid Post. Biscuits, bacon, ham washed down with very welcome hot tea. Shortly after the men get the equipment together & about

6.30 am we start down the valley on our way to the beach. On the way down I took note of the country We are walking down a valley which looks as if it must be the bed of a torrent of water in the wet weather season. It runs down between broken ridges & opens on to the beach a few hundred yards below the main landing place which is now known as ANZAC cove. This valley in part is known as Shrapnel Valley & the Valley of Death. This is on account of the daily plastering with Shrapnel that the Turks give it. However, in the rising ground on either side are now made a great no of funk holes so that if the shrapnel starts one can take shelter. As we went down 2 or 3 shrapnel bursts occurred but did not get very near us. One sees a white puff above & then the bullets come pattering around on the ground just like rain. You get the impression that they would do very little harm if they hit you, judging by the apparently harmless way they patter on the ground but appearances are deceptive as the majority of the wounded could tell. Up & down Shrapnel valley there is constant traffic, Mules & men carrying stores & water & stretcher

parties bringing down wounded. The litter of equipment about the path is astounding everything one might say from a tooth brush to a rifle. One could do a flourishing business as a 2nd handstore with all this stuff in Anzac. When we got on to the beach we were directed where to go & on finding 3rd Bn HdQuarters I reported to Major Bennett 2nd in command. We have to bivouac on the beach which is sheltered by a perpendicular cliff about 20 ft high & about 20 yds from the waters edge. Here we started to make shelters in the face of the cliff while the rank & file scooped out shallow trenches about 18" deep, close & parallel to one another, & at rt angles to the waters edge. The cliff protects these & indeed as we were making them we saw the bullets & occasional shrapnel dropping into the water a few yards from the beach. The bullets hiss through the air or very often make a noise like a mosquito singing This hiss is heard continuously while now & then a bullet which goes close to one goes past with a whiz & makes one inclined to jump. However one gets quite used to them in an hour or two.

It is notable that there are practically no casualties from these passing bullets. Only 3 or 4 men were hit during the day out of three battalions. The men were straggling in all the day & at midday there was a roll call when the Battalion was found to be barely half strength. I watched the men come on to the beach & all looked absolutely done. Their faces were drawn & yellow & the majority as soon as they got on to the beach simply flung themselves down & in a few seconds were fast asleep. I noticed the reaction in them after the tremendous strain of the last four days. Although they were full of life right up till the time they left the trenches, once they got onto the beach they just seemed to collapse & were asleep in a second. Most awoke just before 1 pm & then had a dip quite heedless of the bullets Then it was I noticed that their color had come back & most looked fit as a fiddle again. But the nerve strain had a deeper & less apparent effect. If a man were spoken to or called, he would jump as if he were shot & I am sure that in spite of their spirits reviving so quickly, if one had spoken harshly to those men on this day they probably would

have wept. However a rest during the afternoon worked wonders & that night you might have thought yourself back at Mena as you listened to their jokes & their stories. During the morning I saw a few sick & dressed a few wounds & fixed up the sanitation. As I had nothing to do in the afternoon, I thought I had better try & get out to the Minnewaska & get my gear. After waiting an hour on the jetty I got aboard a pinnece, telling the naval transport officer that I was on special duty & was soon on the Minnewaska again.

Here I got my sleeping bag & waterproof sheet & toilet gear, a service uniform, a singlet, 1 pr underpants 3 prs socks & ½ doz H’Kerchiefs I also brought my camera off & about 3 Doz. films. While waiting for the pinnece I had a look at ANZAC & the country on either side. I will not attempt to describe it further than I have as photographs that I have taken shew much better than a lame description would. Inland from Gaba Tepe about 2 way to Maides which here is only 4 ½ miles across on the narrows, can be seen evidence of a big fire. It looks as if some stores in a

village even the village itself are on fire It must be 4 - 5 miles from where I stand & one can see a huge column of dense black smoke & very high flames. I would very much like to see it by dark. But about 5 pm the pinnece is ready for me so I go ashore. We had a quiet trip to the landing place no shrapnel going anywhere near us for which I was duly thankful. I found the

Battalion settled down in their new quarters with the 2nd Battn to the left of them & the 1st &
Entry.57:
to their right. Had a good tea of Bully Beef & Biscuit pie & Biscuit & jam pudding. Biscuits soaked in water after being broken into small pieces mixed with jam & warmed over the fire. It made a very dainty sweet indeed. Whenever I chew the biscuits "au naturel" I feel very pleased that I have sound & strong teeth. Even at this early stage of the game I have had a good many men reporting with broken teeth & broken tooth plates.

After tea I went for a walk up & down the beach with Major Bennett who told me many interesting things. Amongst other things he told
Entry.58:
how Brigadier Maclaurin & Major Irvine lost their lives It appears that Major Bennett sent a message to Brigade H.Q, asking for artillery fire on a target that he described The valley was swept with shrapnel at the time & snipers were very active yet the two officers decided to come up & see the target for themselves. They exposed themselves on the side of a ridge & were shot by a sniper or snipers.

Considering the nature of the country it can best be described by saying that it is very like the broken scrubby country around Middle habour in Sydney. There appears to be a fair quantity of good spring water & some small creeks which drain the steep ridges The ridges are very waterworn & all of a loose sandy & clayey nature. Our line is roughly a semicircle about 3 miles long but which is at no point much further from the sea than 900 yds. the sea of course forms the base line of this area.

The climate is delightful & very like that of N.S.W. & there are absolutely no flies at present. I heard a good yarn about a stretcher bearer after tea. He was walking up the valley.

with a stretcher over his shoulder. It was also carrying a Bill hook. Suddenly he was confronted by a Turk who at once put up his rifle to shoot him when he knocked the Turk over with the stretcher & then finished him off with the Bill hook. The man who told me this swears it is true. I also was yarning to Lt Street who is a son of Justice Street of Sydney. He was at Pauls College just after I left. He is a very decent chap & was very well spoken of by his senior officers for his work during the landing & the four days following
Entry.59:
Everybody is awakened before 4 am by the roar of big shells over head. These are Turkish big guns, & it is thought that they belong to the Goeben who has been making a hobby of coming down to the Narrows & firing across our position at the Transports. Some of the shells fall into the water just in front of us & as a precaution, the Colonel made all the men sleeping near the waters edge come up & take shelter under the cliff However two of our warships quickly got to work & sent a nice little lot over. One of the warships was just in front of us & the

roar of guns was terrific. Of course we got the full benefit. It was most interesting to hear these shells roaring overhead, the sound gradually dying away in the distance About one hour later the Turkish land batteries started their morning shrapnel strafe & the men had to take shelter under the cliff once more. This is a most friendly cliff as it goes vertically up for about 20 ft. It has to be treated with the greatest respect however & any cutting under it to make a cave dugout at once will bring down a few tons on top of one if you happened to be near. The cliff consists merely of crumbling sandy clay stuff. In fact this formation appears to be common to the whole area & already there have been several accidents Only the night before last four men who had dug in on the side of a hill suddenly had the whole thing cave in & completely bury them. When they were dug out they were all dead. Where my Dugout is the wall is absolutely vertical & even at this I look with suspicion I am thoroughly enjoying sleeping out in the open & slept like a

top during the night. The simple life is a great stunt

To continue about the shrapnel bout. Already the men call it the reveille, so regularly has it been commencing at about 5 am. It is very nice to lie in ones sleeping bag & watch the stuff whiz over your head into the water, knowing of course that it cannot get you. I got up about 6 am & visited the 1st Fd Amb. who are camped directly at the back of us, only about 100 yds away. Wassell Kay & Welch are still cooking their own food which seems to me superfluous, needless to say I told them so. They agreed that the best thing would be to appoint cooks as the regular 1st Fd Amb cooks have not landed. Of course in the Battalion I am attached to Hd Quarters for which there is a separate mess & to which sit down the O.C. Lt Col Owen, the 2nd in Command Major Bennett (who by the way late last night received orders that he was appointed in command of the 4th Bn, whose OC was killed during the 1st 4 days), the adjutant Howell Price, the signalling officer Lt Goldring & the M.O, myself

One of O.C.s orderlies is cook & he serves up some good stuff. All day the Battalion rests & waits for stragglers who had been separated from their unit & who keep coming in all day. It is touching to see how these late comers are greeted by their mates as they come in They are always told that they were given up as dead & certainly you would think they had been away for years so warm is the greeting to them. All through the day the men bathe & there are practically no casualties. It is certainly marvellous that this is so because the bullets keep dropping right in among them & round them their troubles for such common or garden stuff is the impression one gets.

Looking at them & seeing them laughing & skylarking one would think they were on a big picnic.

A few casualties of course occurred & then you would hear mighty shouts all along the line for STRETCHER BEARERS. Several times there were false alarms & SB’s would have a little trip for nothing I had a swim myself in the morning

& felt much cleaner afterwards as there is a good deal of dust about. Needless to say I went in where the bullets were least numerous. Just at sundown there is another shrapnel strafe from the Turks but no damage down our way

At 9 p.m. Went to bed & was soon fast asleep.
Entry.60:
Spent a quiet morning during which there was a small sick parade of minor cases & a few wounds to dress. We have heard that we shall probably move up to the trenches at any time today so everyone is sticking close round the Bivouac.

About 3.30 pm. orders are received. The Battalion is to move up into the Firing line & relieve the troops at present in the trenches about the centre of the line.

We set off shortly after 5 pm. just as the Turks started their evening hate. As we went up Shrapnel valley we were in luck & had no casualties, although the shrapnel was bursting pretty close.

We branched off Shrapnel valley about 1/4 mile from the beach & turned up a track leading up another valley at rt angles to the sea. (Shrapnel Valley is obliquely inland from the sea).

& going straight up to the top of the ridge. Going along this path we saw much evidence of war. Saw 5 or 6 dead mules lying about & also two dead men who had been killed on the path & who were lying at the side of the path, where later they would be collected by a burying party & removed for Burial. But so used to these sights had everyone become that no one looked at them twice. We were halted at the top of the valley & our battalion was put in the ½ formed supporting trenches where they would be ready to move into the trenches & take the place of the marines early next morning. I selected a position for a Regimental aid post situated about 200 yds from the top of the valley, right on the main track to which all tracks from the different companies of the Bn converged so that if any man wounded or sick wished to get on to the main path he had to come thro’ the aid post.

Although it was dusk I started the men on to digging & by about 9 pm we had a Dugout cut well into the Hill. (I have a photograph). Went to bed early & slept well being awak-

ened for only 3 cases.

I am forgetting to put in a rather exciting incident As we were digging in the twilight soon after we got to the top of the valley I walked up to the top of the valley with Sgt Malone to report to Bn H.Q. We had not gone far when we heard a great uproar below. We looked down & saw 7 men rushing down from the direction of the trenches & thought at first they were Turkish prisoners with some of our men in pursuit. At once every body started yelling directions. Some advised shooting, majority yelled Don’t shoot, stop these men etc. etc. They only got to the path & were stopped & at once an immense crowd collected around. Out of curiosity I sent the Sergeant down who shortly after rejoined me & told what had happened.

It appears that these were seven Britishers who were stationed in an advanced Trench when suddenly some Turks got in amongst them. They apparently threw down their arms & bolted most of them stopped at a rear trench but this party that we had seen had not stopped running. The 1st thing they said when they got into the valley was Which is the quickest way to retire to the beach.

This was a unit of which the majority appeared to be boys just out of school & the poor fellows were frightened out of their senses. This was not the first time that certain units bolted out of the trenches & in several instances our men had to be sent into the trenches post haste to stop disaster & retake abandoned trenches. I will not mention names of units but some that I have seen appear to be extremely raw & only half trained. This unfortunately has already created an unfavorable impression amongst the rank & file of our Divisions. They are prone to judge all home troops by these units.

Another thing I might mention. Everybody is uneasy about Turkish snipers & it is thought that there are some in concealed positions commanding this valley. As a precaution all AMC men were told to take off their white armlets as they offer a conspicuous target. And again no fires are allowed after dark at all.

Another precaution that may be seen has manifested itself in the soldiers head gear. Caps of all ranks have been made into soft slouch caps by removing the stiffening

wire. They are supposed to blend with the landscape by this means & certainly they are by no means so conspicuous.
Entry.61:
5 am. awakened by the usual reveille of Turkish shrapnel I find at this early hour that the site of the aid post is well chosen. It is backed by a steep almost vertical rise & over this the shrapnel is coming. It is falling just in front of the aid post but it looks as if it cannot possibly get into the Dug out, unless of course the Turks use Howitzers which they do not appear to have at the present time. The Shrapnel continues on & off all the morning & a few wounded & sick keep coming in at odd hours during the day. I did not go far away from the aid post on account of this & also as I had to make the Dug out ship shape. The Dug out was completed by midday. The floor space is roughly circular & opens on to the path so

 

On this circular floor 3 people can be full length with their feet sticking into the part leading to the path

The walls are undercut so that the opening at the top which will be roofed over is much smaller in area than the floor. On one side of the path leading in We have cut shelves on which we have put the panniers with surgical appliances all ready laid out for emergency surgery.

After lunch the men started digging a home of their own a little way down the path big enough to hold three lying down

Just over the other side of the path we have made a fire place & a few yards up on the same side is a little spring which reluctantly gives out about a Kerosine tin full of water twice a day. This will save our men going down to the Water depot at the foot of the valley to a certain extent.

During the morning I visited my neighbors. About 15 yds up the path & on the opposite side Capt Kane AAMC. 2nd Bn. has his aid post while about 30 yds up on our side is Capt Tebbutt AMC of the 4th Bn.

About 40 yds. down the path & on our side is a Field Ambulance Station belonging to the R.M.L.I. This is a very elaborate Dug out

with several Dugouts cut out of the hill & communicating one with another. There are two English medicoes in charge at this station who I cannot help saying, it looks as if they would like to be thought rather superior to "beastly Colonials" The path on which we are situated is a supply route to several units, consequently there is a great deal of traffic up & down. What chiefly impresses one is the fearless way in which the Indians bring up the Mules, laden with supplies & water. Although the path is liberally peppered with shrapnel most of the day, these chaps keep going & do not shew the slightest concern. The mules are remarkably intelligent & very docile & are as sure footed as goats on these steep slopes. The stretcher bearers of the 3rd Fd Amb. have also to go up & down this path & this they do all day in spite of the shrapnel bursting all around them. Today already they have had two or three casualties.

In the afternoon Major Stokes came up to see around & gave me formal instructions as regards sanitation. He is on special Sanitation duty & in particular is responsible for the purity of the water supply. We are getting

a great part of the water from wells sunk in the different valleys. This water is sterilised with Chloride of Lime. Our men of 3rd Bn are settling down in trenches at the top of the valley & have a great deal of trench construction in front of them.
Entry.62:
No question of any forward move. The men are very active digging & other wise organising the defense of the position. Had a few wounded men coming into the Dressing station up till midday. Also a few sick. In the Afternoon I decided to go around the trenches & went up shortly after 2 pm. to Bn. Hd Quarters with Sgt Malone. (Malone by the way has been promoted Sgt. in recognition of his bravery & good work during last week. He is a gem as regards AMC work & in civil life belonged to a Govt Asylum near Goulburn. Outside the H.Q. we met Major Storey, Capt. Conrickson AMC. & Capt Smith 3rd Bn. who came ashore for the 1st time this morning. He was on the City of Benares & there I got to know him quite well, a very decent sort. We all set off into the winding trenches Capt Smith taking a rifle in case he should

be able to get a pot at the Turks. We went into the firing Trench & admired the view & also the smell of dead Turks thro a periscope. The bullets sound unpleasantly close as they whiz close overhead & it is quite obvious that one must keep ones head well down. We could also see the Turks throwing out earth as they dug about 80 yds. away. Altogether we stayed in the trenches about one hour finding plenty to interest us. In most places the Trenches are now dug about 5 ft deep & of course they will be dug deeper still.

As we went along we were in single file & Capt Smith who was just in front of Sgt Malone & myself stopped several times to talk to men he knew. We waited behind till he went on again. And then a tragedy ended our afternoon in the Trenches

We had turned into the Communicating trench to emerge from the trenches on to Bn H.Q. & had gone a little way when Smith stopped again to talk to a man.

I was just behind & for some reason or other decided to push past & not wait for him. I got past him & had just turned a corner 

about 10 yds farther on when there was a deafening bang, we hurried on & had only gone another five yards when we heard another report. Then there were yells for the Doctor so Sgt Malone & I went back. There was poor Smith lying on his back in the Trench with the upper part of his neck shot completely away, & a large pool of blood around. He was just gasping his last breath. We just had time to look at him & lift him to one side & run into a Dugout a few yds away where Col Bennett & Lt Massie were sheltering when another shell went off almost in the same place. I think it gave us all a nasty turn to see poor Smith lying dead there with this horrible gash in his neck. Particularly sad it was to think of poor Smith alive & well a few minutes before & who had just landed that morning. I remembered the poor chap on board the Transport shewing me with pride a picture of his wife & two children. War with a vengeance & I thought I had become quite accustomed to it. But now I think I could not have

realised what an awful thing it is till I had seen a man I knew personally suddenly & violently butchered. However, mercifully, Death was practically instantaneous & he could not have felt anything.

As Sgt Malone & I walked back to our Aid post our minds were full of this & I made up my mind that I was certainly not going to do any more aimless wandering about the trenches unless I had a specific duty to perform. I do not think I am superstitious but it was certainly uncanny to think how acting on a sudden impulse, Malone & I had pushed past Smith & so got out of the danger zone for we must have been hit if we had stopped Went to bed early & slept on & off during the night. I was frequently awakened by heavy firing of the Turks & we thought several times there was an attack commencing.

Tuesday 4th May About 7 am. Capt. Douglas 3rd Bn was brought in to the Aid post "in extremis" He has a bullet wound which is evidently perforating the liver & I don’t think much of his chances. We rendered 1st Aid put a red ticket on him & sent him off

post haste to the Cas. Clearing Hospital. About 7.30 am a wounded Turkish prisoner was sent down to the Aid post.

The poor little devil had tumbled into our Fire Trench & as he did not know any English he was promptly shot thro’ the neck & also had bayonet thrusts through the loin & chest. The latter a serious wound implicating the lung. He was very collapsed when we got him so we promptly fed him up with hot coffee & warmed up Bully Beef & biscuits & his gratitude was touching in the extreme In spite of the pain when he breathed he tried to smile & kiss our hands. Then when we gave him an Egyptian cigarette he lay back & puffed away quite at his ease & as contented as he possibly could be although when he 1st came down. He looked on us as if he expected us to finish him off at any moment.

Presently a man came by who knew a little Turkish & the Turk then told us about himself. He had been without food for 4 days & had crawled over to our Trench to give himself up That the German officers were flogging & knifing the Turks to make them go on during

 

the 1st week.

Also the Turks are frightened to surrender to our men as their officers tell them we give no quarter. As soon as this wounded Turk had rested & revived a little we sent him down with an urgent order for admission to Hospital ship. I think he has a fair chance of recovery, we all hope so, as was such a pathetic object, with the look of a hunted animal when we 1st got him. Needless to say our big hearted Australians well nigh killed him with hospitality while he was at the Dressing Station & everybody passing wanted to have a look at him

Just before he left Col Braund 2nd Bn. called in & had a yarn, Capt Kane 2nd Bn also came down so I took a photograph of them both.

The former told us something about the Ruses of the enemy during the
Entry.63:
few days.

They stripped the uniforms from all the dead Australians they came across & some of the German officers even came amongst our men dressed in these uniforms, in order to give orders to our men that would lead them into traps. Some of our men discovered a German officer so dressed & promptly took

him to a quiet spot & shot him. Our men now are very suspicious & will drastically search anyone, be he officer or man.

Up till midday attended to Dressings, sick & a few fresh casualties. All the morning the Shrapnel was bursting around the top part of the valley & several times we had to shelter well inside the Dug out as the bullets were falling on our front door step no Casualties however in our unit Just after lunch saw Col Braund again who stopped a few minutes to talk. Went up to Bn H.Q. & saw the adjutant & spoke about sanitation matters. Went to bed early but did not sleep much as the firing was incessant & very heavy.
Entry.64:
Before Bkfast we heard that Col Braund was killed during the night. It is said that he was going around & inspecting his lines after 10 pm. with no one to accompany him a habit to which he was particularly prone. A Sentry challenged him, but he did not answer or stop, so the sentry fired & later found that Col Braund had received the bullet & was quite dead. It came as a shock to us, as it was only yesterday he was here.

alive & well & having his photograph taken.
